author: oaklandmatt
content: The easiest thing is just different mic positioning. The classic is to stand a few feet back from the mic and record BVs that way. If you have multiple mics, just try a different mic for BVs. See if you like the contrast. It's a creative decision more than anything else. Close mic, stacked harmonies with the same mic as the lead vocal also sound nice. Just depends what you're after. Experiment and let your ears decide!

author: Slow Hand
content: One approach that hasn't been mentioned is using a different singer/singers for the backgrounds so that they contrast the lead vocalist. That can add a ton of character to a track and keep the timbre from being same-y.

author: Slow Hand
content: Or, if you don't have other singers handy, adopt a "character" when performing your backgrounds. Kendrick Lamar is great at this. If he's tracking a chorus (group of vocalists) responding to his lyrics they'll have a distinct affect to differentiate the different narrative personalities.

author: Slow Hand
content: Trey Spruance once described his process for multi-tracking a string section using one violinist (I'm paraphrasing): "After each string take I give the player a new prompt about their personality: "Now you're second violin and you're gunning for first-chair's spot, so you're gonna be trying a little too hard and playing just a hair too loud to get the conductor's notice. You've got something to prove." or "Now you're 6th chair and you're just happy to be here. Your vibrato is going to be a little lax." Etc, etc, etc.

author: Slow Hand
content: So I'd sum it up as: Unless you're seeking homogeneity in your backgrounds, start with the performer/performance aspect.

author: Slow Hand
content: Oh cool. Well you may already know then, but it's a nylon string guitar, which is going to sound and play differently than a steel string. Nylon is going to sound more mellow in tone than a jangly/bright steel string. The neck/fingerboards are very different in shape too. If you're not already familiar with nylon string guitar, you may want to lay your hands on it and make sure that it's a sound you're interested in.

author: hendrick
content: so are metal strings usually more sought after?

author: oaklandmatt
content: @hendrick these are awesome!

author: Slow Hand
content: FYI, They're playing a steel string in the Usher video, but it's still a nylon on the recording.

author: Slow Hand
content: The other big difference is the neck/fingerboard shapes. Steel string necks are typically akin to electric guitars. If you can play electric guitar you'll pick up a steel string easy, while a nylon guitar takes a little bit of adjustment because the fretboards are much wider and the string spacing is wide to match. It's nothing you can't get used to, but it can lead you to different playing styles on each.

author: Slow Hand
content: Now all that said, Ovation guitars are somewhat unique. They've got that plasticky back, instead of wood, which can make for a more biting, articulate, tone. They can sometimes be a bit hybrid in their sound and form factor. So again, just put your hands on the guitar, if you can, and see how it feels/sounds to you. If it sounds good and it feels good it is good.

author: cian riordan
content: Since you'd be going into a mic-input on the MPDI-4 (the MPEQ-1 does give you a line-in, but not the same gain)... you could certainly do this and you'd definitely get distortion, whether it would be similar to recording with the pre-amp, the answer is 'not really'. Could it yield some fun effects? Maybe?! I'm sorta with Matt... if you're already in the computer, and unless you're sending out to something with a shitton of tubes or transformers, you're probably best staying in the box. Some 'pre-amps' that I do come out of the box for distortion on a regular basis are: Ampex 351 (god bless this thing) and the Scully 280. But I'm looking for real distortion that I'm typically using in parallel, nothing subtle. I use Spectre/Saturn/Decapitator/Neutron for that stuff.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I send shit out of the box all the time, because it’s more fun for me, I’ll send drums out to guitar pedals to get fun sounds, like the EHX bass micro synth does some weird shit to drums.

The second conversion isn’t a problem IMO, to me you leave the box because you can’t get the sound or you’ll be more inspired to get a different sound because you have your hands on the knobs and can turn two at one time which you can’t really do with a mouse. 

That’s why I still send things out to my distressor or my LCA2B(tubes) , maybe try it and find a sound you like, then try and hear if you can duplicate the sound you like using one of the saturation plugins in the box, if you can, then no need to send out again, but if you can’t, then you’ll know that you’ll do that thing again. 

Maybe it’s just more fun to send out to the gear instead of staying in the box?!?

content: So you're looking for what Moog calls *multi-trigger* on their newer synths which makes the filter or amp envelopes re-trigger every time you gate a key.

author: Slow Hand
content: Depends on what effect you want, but yeah. Filter decay re-triggers the filter envelope and loud decay triggers the amp envelope. Having either switch off will cause that synth component to respond in a legato way.

author: mixedbyKerim
content: Its a bar/lounge setting , couple artists are going live,

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. I'm used to having more control as an MD for artists and not handing it off to another party and having it out of my hands. An important aspect of these live performance mixes would be consistency of level between them all. Don't send the artist out with one track that's super loud and another that's considerably quieter. Like @Rollmottle says, you want the live tracks to be predictable and consistent and whoever is handling the tracks should ensure that they're level-matched relative to each other. You want to do your best to ensure that the live tracks are all reaching the live engineer at a consistent and unwavering level, so that they aren't getting any curveballs from the person running the tracks.

author: Slow Hand
content: So whatever you and the artist decide, do your best to make the live tracks you print have a consistent level. You can't control the mixes they get from others, so you'll need to talk to the artist and see what they're already using.

author: Deleted User
content: Hi, Matt I have question for the next live, whats the difference between using sends on buses VS sends on Audio when mixing like Reverb Delays. Thank you.

author: oaklandmatt
content: maybe someone can chime in but i'm not really sure what you mean. there's no difference if the audio on the buss and the audio track is the same

author: cian riordan
content: No difference sonically, just all workflow, resource management, etc. Sends harken to a time when outboard effects were limited, so it made sense to send things to a plate so you didn't have to have 20 giant EMT plates in your studio to put on each track you wanted reverb on. Nowadays, in the computer, it's less important and just comes down to workflow. Sometimes some mixes call for a more uniform reverb to tie tracks together... in this case putting it on a send makes more sense. But there's no rules anymore, and if you don't like that workflow, then fuck it. Do it your way. There's no right or wrong on this.

author: peterlabberton
content: Only difference I can think of is if you have effects going *before* any processing on a buss, i.e. drum tracks going to a buss, sending to a reverb also going into the same buss, as opposed to sending to a reverb from the drum buss itself. Is that what you’re getting at, @Deleted User ?

author: Slow Hand
content: It may be worth moving the location of both the mic and the performer. As @cian riordan says, you may be getting some build-ups because the performer, the mic, or both are placed in the middle of an acoustic node that is accentuating or sucking the energy out of particular frequencies at that point in the room. Try moving performer and mic by increments of 12"-18"  and listen to whether or not that improves the sound or works against it.

author: alecdibell2
content:
@thejadenmejia this is something that will probably be different for all of us. I’d consider what you’re recording (just vocals? Full band? Etc) Do you want to have a day rate, hourly rate, or song rate? For me, I prefer day rates + the consideration of how many different things I’m recording. 

I’d also consider if you are only recording, or if you are also going to be mixing the project. You could stack the two rates on top of each other, or work something out with the artist where it’s “Normally I charge this for recording and this for mixing, but if I do the whole project, i’ll give you this deal”. Not necessary, but slightly dropping my recording rate and mixing the whole project is something i’ve done in the past

author: alecdibell2
content: @thejadenmejia i think it’s really going to just come from trial and error as far as how you would like to price those things. Definitely see what’s common is your local area and your output vs others. Don’t be scared to up your rate if the value is there

author: thejadenmejia

author: Eric Martin

author: thejadenmejia

author: Eric Martin
content: the more you charge, the more people will value you too, have you listened to the “Attack and Release Show” that podcast talks about rates a lot and they firmly believe in upping your rate sooner than later.

author: thejadenmejia

author: peterlabberton
content: You can also approach it, as I did for quite a while, from a monthly cost angle. If you want to work 20 days a month, maybe build in a healthy buffer so that if you only book 10, you’ll still make ends meet. Make a day rate from there, and an hourly rate from that. I’ve played this out several times over the years, and it usually comes out pretty close to where most working engineers settle in whichever city I was in at the time.

author: jonmatteson
content: Try moving the kick out 4-6 inches from the kick and get them in phase on the way in. This can help the low end “bloom” nicely and give you a really full sound. As always though, the source/drummer has a lot to do with the sound. Make sure the drummer isn’t burying the beater as you will get a lot less low end if they are!

author: peterlabberton

author: longstoryshort
content: i love that "gain reduction" plug's sound - its meant for vocals but sounds awesome in a small parallel with my drums.  it does however add too many harmonics to my kick..

author: Rollmottle
content: why do you need the kick going to the same bus as the other stuff? just leave it on its own channel and process it on its own. side chain your drum bus to the kick if you need the kick's groove.

author: Eric Martin
content: I’ve been parallel processing the kick and snare and drums separately and leaving the bus pretty clean with good success, it’s harder to get a handle on the mix for me if I’m processing the drums as a whole, I usually leave the bus without any processing if maybe only a tiny over clipper as protection, but even then I don’t hit the bus hard, music hits harder IMO with more dynamics and running parallel allows me to get the density of the processing with the impact of the transients staying intact.

author: longstoryshort
content: Ah track comp could be interesting.  I've been meaning to try that thing. Kick tuning and all that is absolutely important...in phase especially with the bassline. Thanks!

author: longstoryshort
content: Some notes on kick "tuning" - I actually dislike when a kick lands on a fundamental in dance music.  I've been moving toward having the kick constantly pitching down, and never actually sitting on a note.  This gives it a LOT of power, and as long as you're able to make it stay in phase with your bassline most of the time (if you're playing multiple notes this is obviously impossible for all the time) the tuning becomes "implied" based on the rest of the tone. I hope that makes sense.

author: longstoryshort
content: I also do like a very short kick, so it doesn't always get to the fundamental anyways, this allows my bass to be the bass, and not a kick.  A lot easier for sidechain/mix/etc.

author: Slow Hand
content: Seconded. Sometimes things can be *too* consonant. It's a strange feeling, when everything is perfectly tuned and little bit of beating frequencies are just what's needed.

author: longstoryshort
content: it is also nice to tune snares a semitone off - if you really want it to rip at least.  i'm a big fan of this.  i also don't think the fundamental we think is really the fundamental.  it's possible the snare fundamental is like, 3hz and everything else is just an overtone, which would make sense why it usually feels somewhat acceptable compared to a note, even when it's "out of tune"

author: $$C Z00BOY
content: sounds cool, will try this!

author: longstoryshort
content: i guess to clarify more, a real snare drum (not synthetic) would be impossible to have a plain fundamental at like 200hz.  two skins, that maybe could resemble one single string of an instrument - it's technically impossible for both skins to be tuned the same.  if they're a few HZ apart, the fundamental would technically be in the single digits.  so the rest would be overtones.

author: Slow Hand
content: That’s so interesting that y’all have to tame the midrange. I have the opposite issue: I usually need to bring up the midrange. I’m generally a subtractive mixer and am cutting out a lot of resonances and whistle-tones in the sounds that I have. It has the effect of bringing down the midrange as a whole which makes me need to turn up those instruments. I end up having to force myself to be more aggressive with the mids.

author: kidcutler
content: I think a lot of it comes from over mixing, the softening the shaper does for me keeps me from thinking i need to mix or reduce something, the less moves the better when you’re trying to not fuck up the vibe of someone else’s record

author: Slow Hand
content: Good to know. I’ve definitely had that problem in the past. It’s quite often on my own material. I have a far easier time mixing other people’s music because the blueprint is already laid out before me and it’s easier to know when it’s too far.

author: peterlabberton
content: Harsh midrange is my least favorite thing and I spend a lot of effort fighting it. Regardless of whether I’m mixing something I engineered/produced, or something from someone else, I usually start by muting most things and building the song back gradually. As I piece things back in I always have an ear out for resonant pokey stuff and just try to address it ASAP. That’s either through using spectral shaper (very new to me but awesome) or soothe, or just notching stuff with an EQ. I personally avoid doing any of this on the mix bus—if I’m doing it on busses it’ll be some kind of subgroup. Once things are nice and clean, you can boost a lot to get clarity/aggression/etc. etc.. I will say since you mentioned working late at night, I feel getting a decent volume out of my monitors is pretty revealing for this. I don’t mix all that loud, but I definitely have a decent level going. My goal is always to be able to crank things and not have harsh stuff poking at my eardrums!

author: Zack Hames
content:
Question about this setup I saw posted today:

I sometimes see overhead placement like this, and I have two thoughts:

How are they panned? Which one is capturing the “left” or “right” sides? I feel like them both being pointed essentially at the snare would be kind of a wide mono ish sound. Anyone do this setup? 

Also, I feel like they’re pretty high, and at a certain point in my experience, overheads being high up end up sounding roomy and unfocused. Maybe that is the goal?

Not trying to criticize at all, I know whoever is making this knows what they’re doing 100%, but curious if anyone can explain techniques and goals from a OH setup like this.

author: David Fuller
content: That looks like a pretty basic spaced pair kind of thing to me?

author: Zack Hames
content: I guess I think of that as the mics being pointed straight down or angled away from each other even slightly. This is a common setup but it’s always befuddled me.

author: peterlabberton
content: Yeah, it’s the mics being angled *in* that looks odd to me as well. I feel like I see this more in live sound, but it doesn’t really make sense to me either.

author: cian riordan
content: I will say having things pointed at the snare, in phase (if they are), will yield a very complete drum sound. I like my overheads to capture the sides a bit more, but this technique is a good compliment to give some stereo imaging while maintaining a strong center. Again, I’d never put my overheads out in Kansas like that, but to each their own. Maybe they were chasing something! I’m usually a foot off the cymbals, if even.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Question:

I frequently find that in writing sessions artists want to start tracking their vocal/piano/guitar ideas as soon as they start having them, often before drum grooves are figured out. In my experience laying down drums last in a production usually turns out to be a total mess with various grooves often not quite locking. 

How do y’all handle the quick flow of the early stages of these productions? Am I in the wrong state of mind by trying to get things right early on? Do you end up retracking a lot later? Do y’all not have this problem because y’all just have impeccable rhythm?

author: Zack Hames
content: This is a huge part of my workflow. If people record themselves at home with a collab, I’ll insist they send me a demo that I can make a rhythm track for real quick that I’ll build just for them to record themselves to

author: Zack Hames
content: To answer the flow question: it just needs to be made quickly. 5 minutes or so. Doesn’t need to be crazy, just needs to fit the song and be easy to play to.

author: Eric Martin
content: the best songs IMO, can be sung, full stop. Then while you’re singing, you feel the pull of the rhythm of the song is really strong.

author: Rob Domos
content:
My general issue isn’t usually with finding the pattern. That’s often pretty easy for me. I think the issue  comes with rhythmic feel. Like I end up with slight flams between the drums and the previously recorded material because of slightly disagreeing swings. It happens because a lot of times I steal the groove from loops and I really struggle with trying to program something with great time feel after the fact without the crutch of a groove pool, and a lot of times the performer will have their own groove that I then have to match in my programming and it’s not as intuitive as lining up grooves against transient heavy drum loops. 

I might just need to drill my rhythm harder

author: kidcutler

author: kidcutler
content: And for where I am buying they will reassess your taxes and raise them based on square footage of foundation

author: sethearnest
content: @kidcutler and @Rollmottle are nailing it. One other thing to consider re: the value-add vs. not to a future buyer is location/city. In Nashville, something like this is probably more valuable to more people than even LA, and certainly more so than any other city I can think of. A purpose-built studio in probably anywhere but Nashville would more likely be seen as a "we'd have to reno that building", whereas a mother-in-law suite vibe used as a studio but still a MIL suite might be more value to more people in most cities.

author: sethearnest
content: I'm actually going through a similar thought process right now re: how to build an external building, so fresh on my mind.

author: cian riordan
content: I was lucky that my garage was separated from my house. It was an old derelict shed at best, but it had a foundation and rough structure which saved me a boatload of money. If you have to pour a new slab -- and especially if you're going to do plumbing -- it will be expensive and you'll be doing enough work to justify getting permits involved so you can claim resale if you ever sell your house.

author: sethearnest
content:
When I get in questionable drums, thoughts always go first to checking polarity between all mics and their relationships with one another. I'll get a bad session in, then mess around w/polarity and phase relationships a bit, and all the sudden a "There you are, Peter!" happens w/the punch of the drums. 

While exploring that, I'll also pick a mic or pair of mics that sound the most like a drum set, or sound the most like what sort of drums the mix is calling for, then that mic or that pair will be the "drum sound" I focus on (much like @David Fuller mentioned about the OHs or the room mics as a starting point), and all other mics will have to accentuate that drum sound in a good and/or fun/creative way, or they get muted or blown up with Devil Loc to see what that does. 

Same thing with any multi-mic'd source. 3 or 4 mics for one guitar part? Which one sounds the most like a cool guitar? Mute the rest.

author: sethearnest
content: But also as @Zack Hames said, samples are used abundantly where needed.

author: sethearnest
content: Along those lines, also, dropping a metal kick sample over an Americana song probably isn't the move, so when using samples, focus on trying to make sure the sample is a good-sounding version of the intention.

author: cian riordan
content:
If I get through the kick and snare and find things starting to sound too ‘scooped’, I’ll try and fill in some blanks with parallel sansamp or the distortion buss. I like the distortion buss technique because if offers a consistency across all the tracks and you dont just have a distorted snare drum but pristine clean toms. Often its a Decapitator with a low shelf going into it killing some low end. I’ll solo this buss, get it to sound crunchy but not messy, then un-solo, bring the fader to neg-infinity, and blend it into taste. You’d be surprised how much excitement you get without totally fucking up the aesthetic of the drums.

As for samples? Sure! I’ve you’ve gone all-balls on these tracks and you’re still lacking what you think you need, then no shame in supplementing with samples. ‘Supplement’ being the key word here. I use the Massey DRT to extract MIDI from the kick & snare mics and then use Battery to trigger my samples. I have a few samples that just solve various problems for me. Sometimes just giving me the low end sub, or a 100 cycle knock. They can be helpful to punch your way through phasing issues and really get the meat and potatoes of the rhythm track holding its own. I will never ‘replace’ with a sample… there’s always something useful in the recorded track if you try hard enough.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I have a bit of a weird technical question I can’t wrap my head around. That I’ve never really thought about before. (might be over thinking it). I’m gonna completely simplify and exaggerate. When we talk about making room in a mix, usually we usually talk about giving each sound it’s own space in the mix. I understand this from a frequency point of view. But when talking about mono vs wide sounds I’m kinda lost. 

If let’s say i have 2 sounds, one is mono and one is wide.  Would that leave one with more headroom compared to having the same 2 sounds both in mono? 

Or would the wide sound take up more head room, because to make a sound wide, it needs to be different on both sides. But doesn’t that mean that you would have double the amount of signal as you would need two different versions of the same sound playing at once to achieve wideness? 

Fx a mono guitar and a mono vocal both centre vs a completely anti phase guitar and mono vocal. I know the latter will make each sound more intelligible but wouldn’t you at the same time provide more information resulting in less headroom?

author: Zack Hames
content:
I had a visceral, emotional reaction listening to these tracks. As a die hard EV/barefoot fan, getting to dig into these tracks is probably one of the coolest things I’ve ever gotten to do.

@cian riordan , I’ve got some questions if you’re willing to answer or remember:

Are these all UTA pres?

Do you remember what drums you were using?

How are the room mics (U67s) placed? This, alongside the chamber mics, seriously gave me goosebumps to listen to. 

How are the overheads placed? They seem super wide and right over the cymbals but when you add the snare mic it all sounds perfect. 
Is all the saturation on each channel a product of driving the UTA preamps? I’m amazed at how distorted they are when solo-ed and how much it allows them to punch through.


Sorry for my gushing, but this is just the coolest thing ever to me.  Thanks for sharing this.

author: hendrick
content: when mixing live drums, what makes you wanna use gates?

author: oaklandmatt
content: there are other tricks too like triggering room mic gates with the snare drum to get the snare to explode. but that isolation of close mics for attack is the main thing i do

author: David Fuller
content: All of what Matt said, yep

author: David Fuller
content: Anything like toms that aren't playing throughout should be stripped, not just gated

author: David Fuller
content: Unless you're intentionally using them as bleed mics for the snare or whatever (which I don't, drums are phase soup as it stands and I'd rather not complicate it as-is

author: cian riordan
content: To play devils advocate, there's benefits to using gates instead of stripping audio. If you automate the threshold on the gate, then you have the benefit of manipulating the attack, release, and ratio of the gate while mixing. Sometimes i'll find when getting deep into the mix that opening the gates a little bit starts to make things sound a little bit more natural, while keeping the general effect of the gate.

author: David Fuller
content: That's also a valid approach; for me, though, it just ends up being too hard to isolate tom hits from snare hits and I just don't consider it worth the effort. Metal drummers are a special breed, and not usually in a good way.

author: cian riordan
content: But to answer your question, @hendrick, gates just help you keep things focused across multiple drum mics.

author: David Fuller
content: They tend to go really fast but their dynamic control is often total dicks

author: Zack Hames
content: Only thing I can add is sometimes Tom mics will have snare bleed that is undesirable and interferes with the snare sound. Also gating toms can help mask sympathetic tom resonance from kick drum hits. But Sometimes the bleed is helpful for the kick and snare too. Same with hihat bleed Into snare. With a gate, You can turn up the snare without also turning up the hihat (but it’s a lot more complicated than that if it’s a really loud hihat In the snare)

author: oaklandmatt
content: @hendrick yeah this a good shout. what @sethearnest said too. gating gives you to the control to add in the amount of bleed blend you want

author: cian riordan
content: Absolutely! No rules anymore when it comes to this stuff -- whatever works to get you close to what you're hearing in your head.

author: IanDobyns
content: Answer: can run one channel and it will power both.

author: cian riordan
content: not sure how a y-splitter helps you do Mid/Side?

author: IanDobyns
content: Used a Y (fem xlr—>2 male xlr) split to duplicate my signal inside UA Console, and dialed in/flipped phase so I could monitor it on the way in. I couldn’t find a way to duplicate my signal in real time without a delay (virtual input) inside console, so I tried it that way.

author: seb
content: Just for clarification, mid-side technique is a stereo config which would require 2 mics. What you're describing is not mid-side. That said, I'm not sure how you'd do this in UA console but should be easily achievable in any DAW. 2 channels, same inputs, flip phase on 1.

author: IanDobyns
content: So I used two Roswell Delphos (one mid, one for side), but I was concerned about using the Y splitter above to power a single condenser.

author: IanDobyns
content: By doing it with the Y split, doesn’t that accomplish the same thing? So one mic splits off into two inputs?

author: seb
content: Ah! Okay got it. My bad.

author: seb
content: +1 on this but I do see the desire to want to monitor it.

author: cian riordan
content: Oh I see. So you're trying to flip phase on the side mic on one of the y-channels. Sure, but then you need 3 inputs.

author: cian riordan
content: I guess to answer your question, just fire one of the mic pres with phantom and you should be good.

author: IanDobyns
content: Yeah I used a total of three inputs on the way in to do mid/side in this case as opposed to two in and then process in the box

author: IanDobyns
content: I hadn’t used the splitter I had for this purpose, and had been worried about hurting a mic or something. That said, although I used up an extra channel, it was nice to align and work things into my session during the monitoring phase. I have a small but nice sounding room and I think mid/side tended to capture the energy of it a little better than I’d gotten in past recordings, so all in all it was a really cool experiment!

author: Maxim
content: I mean most lawyers might tell you that producers aren’t entitled to the Song’s publishing. But are for sure entitled to a good percentage of the Master’s royalty if it gets released with a label. The likelihood of this happening as well as other factors (like how much cash they have) would determine your upfront fee. But nowadays in HipHop it’s not weird to see producers get pub as well. As beats have a much bigger influence on / or become a part of the song than with other genres. If you can negotiate it, get as much as you can. But decide for yourself what trade offs you’re willing to accept and what upfront fee you’re not willing to go below. To me it just sounds like they’re hyping themselves up and there aren’t any concrete plans on the song being released with a ML.

author: cian riordan
content: I don't work in it a ton, but yeah, the game is won in the low end. It's usually a matter of building up the low end  first and bringing the mix to the brink of crapping out whatever master chain you have without completely falling apart. Then trying to shoe horn in the other elements with aggressive & drastic scooping to maintain the gain structure you've got going with the 808s. Like Jon says often, it's usually about turning things down to gain headroom, and then making it up with low end boosts or high cuts. It's so impressive when it's done right -- shoutout to J.C. -- him and Ali are the best in the game IMHO.

author: thejadenmejia
content:
Let’s start a thread about off days. Like you go in the studio and everything is just wrong and feels bad. What makes this happen? How often do you get them? 

i’m only bringing this up because I walked in the studio today, and it was an absolute disaster from start to finish. I don’t know why I kept going thinking it was going to get better.

author: Zack Hames
content:
It’s usually for me some sort of fatigue or mental block. I’m tired and uninspired, usually from lack of sleep or poor diet. 

I essentially make 99% of my life choices around avoiding this feeling. This includes light exercise (yoga, walking) eating enough decent food, getting enough sleep, and not drinking alcohol or caffeine regularly.

author: Tyler Graham
content: I go through a solid week, two weeks of manic, unbridled work, followed by couple week of inevitable burn out. I anticipate it coming and it doesn’t have the same demoralizing effect that it had when I started. I know that i’m just at the bottom of the sine wave, so to speak. Its pretty essential to vary your work and expand your horizons. When I burn out on mixing, move to production. When I burn out on production, tracking, etc.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Also I find when I’m having a bad work day I end up on my phone a lot more. So removing that from my general area can really help me refocus. 

Also I love to do lists. Writing out a plan can make it way easier to knock things out when you’re having an off day.

author: David Fuller
content: because they aren't balanced circuits

author: David Fuller
content: tl;dr: cables themselves can't be balanced, they're just wire - what makes a circuit "balanced" has to do with having two sources with equal impedance feeding a load with a differential amplifier on the other end.

author: itaylerner
content: Perfect, just what I needed. Thank you both!!

author: David Fuller
content: This is what a basic differential amp looks like. I've labeled it so it's more obvious what everything is. The feedback loop isn't necessary, but is very common because it helps further linearize the circuit (and also in the case of op amps limit their gain, which for something like a common TL071/TL072/TL074 is about 120dB - or a factor of 1,000,000).

author: itaylerner
content: So then in speaker cables, what is the common, if not shielding?

author: itaylerner
content: Really appreciate all of this info btw, hugely helpful.

author: David Fuller
content: It's just a return to ground, basically

author: David Fuller
content: It completes the circuit

author: itaylerner
content: Ahhhh ok got it, makes sense!

author: itaylerner
content: Is the I an integrated circuit?

author: David Fuller
content: The blue triangle represents the op-amp

author: David Fuller
content: I in this case represents current but current basically doesn't apply for our purposes

author: David Fuller
content: we just care about voltage

author: itaylerner
content: Ahhh ok ok got it. Appreciate this, been trying to get deeper into the electrical engineering side of things but it seems like i could spend a lifetime studying fundamentals.

author: Slow Hand
content:
The fact that you're already being paid for your work is a great indicator. Just keep going and developing your existing relationships.

That feeling of "I don't really know what I'm doing" is normal. It happens to most of us. And that's okay. I think you'll be surprised when you someday realize that a tremendous amount of people have no idea what they're doing; even those who seem in control. You do your best in the moment and then build on what you've learned and you do it even better the next time.

Don't be afraid of failure. The most courageous thing that you can do is to put yourself in a situation where you feel vulnerable. You will fail and you will fail again, and finally you will succeed. Then you will find yourself in a situation where you get to fail at bigger, better things. That's the process of self-actualization.

You should repeatedly strive to put yourself in a position that puts you at the edge of your abilities. That very feeling of being uncomfortable is a sign that you're in the right place. Challenge yourself and go for it. Pushing yourself in this way is the path to growth and achievement.

You're doing great.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: A. B. C. D. Incredible insight and advice IME.

author: BatMeckley
content: So much good advice here, but I’ll just add: no one gives you a plaque that says “you’re a producer” or “you’re an artist”. You are because you do. Just keep doing, keep trying to find any avenue to push you’re knowledge/experience/discography forward. Every record you make you’ll learn something new AND you’re already getting paid for your work (win). Spoiler alert: You’ll NEVER feel like you REALLY know what you’re doing. If you do, you’ve lost (I know this must sound odd coming from someone who @cian riordan  thinks is so knowledgeable and brilliant) Satisfaction breeds mediocrity. Music is far too vast for anyone to fully understand    everything in their lifetime. Bake that into the equation as you try to figure out how you feel about where you’re at.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Use EQs with knobs and no frequency analyzer. Your brain will always defer to what you see over what you hear, and if you’re drawing lines and looking at analyzers you’re essentially “seeing” the sound as much as hearing it. Which ultimately is really useful for getting good results and solving problems quickly. But, if you want to focus on what you’re hearing, you have to minimize the visual activity. 
Using a 1073 style eq, your brain will start to connect sounds with numbers, and so you’ll hear something and start thinking “snare needs more 200 and less 600” or whatever, and then you’ll start to associate numbers with abstract concepts like “brightness” or “punch.” 

And it will be your ears not your eyes doing the work 🙌🏻

@Zack Hames is right- the more you do it the better you get at it, and there’s no substitute for time.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Can someone here get technical as to why putting a chorus or Microshift on a delay or reverb where one side is phaseflipped. Makes it Sound less wide? 

My best guess is that its because its essentially making the phase relation ship more then 180 out of phase so it starts becoming more mono again? 

Again i have no clue. What love to talk if someone here knows!

author: ehutton21
content: An additional question for anyone to answer: I’ve gotten projects sent to me where there’s verb panned left and then right—is this technique more prone to phase cancellation issues, and if so, why?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I suppose it would come down to the particulars of a given reverb, but I think your rationale is mostly correct. The verb may already be de-correlating the L/R channels (making them different from each other) in the optimal amount.

Something else to keep in mind is that different frequencies will likely have different amounts of phase rotation from the dry input signal, so flipping the polarity on one channel (left or right) might cause some frequencies to nullify and some to be accentuated. I wouldn't worry about trying to predict these relationships. It's all a mess by design. Use your ears and see what sounds good.

author: Slow Hand
content: A nice flavor of spatialization that hasn't been mentioned can come from FFT manipulation (Fast Fourier Transform). The Michael Norris plugin set have a cool *randomize phase* feature that will wash out a sound slightly in a way that sounds like it's been put in an echo chamber. I love the sound of it. And if i'm not mistaken this technique also folds down to mono really well.

author: ALXCPH
content:
thanks! @Slow Hand & @oaklandmatt. 

Something i've been noticing a lot lately is, when playing with width effects, i keep preferring, sticking to only one type of widening at a time, instead of combining. To me it achieves the "clearest" or most intentional result. For example, for some cool widening on guitar i could use a pingpong slap where one side is phase-flipped. It sounds huge and great, now let's say i also want to chorus it. For some reason it seems to loose some of the width or wow effect of the original widening technique. So i'll usually try a few different effect and see which one i prefer, and 9/10 it always achieves my preferred effect picking one, even tho i like the idea of combining, different techniques to sound "unique". The Diminishing returns seem to work against the sound i like in my earholes. I've noticed in a lot of sessions i've been given or been in, a lot of people seem to love adding a bajillion subtle widening things on their lead vocals and when ever i just choose one and turn it up, people usually ask what crazy voodoo i'm doing. 

This is all in the context of widening a mono or less wide sound.

author: cian riordan
content: It's really just to give you some headroom for processing. Say you have a kick drum thats showing up at 0dBFS (or super hot and limited, or whatever) then you have no room to boost low end without distorting. So turning everything down -6 (or -12 or -3, whatever you want) just gives your processing chain a chance to not fuck things up.

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is a good question.

The short answer is yes and no.  The phase interaction is more dramatic and obvious the closer in level the two sources are. So if you turn one of them WAY louder than the other, even if they're phasing out, it will be way less obvious. If the frequencies (usually the low end) that are fighting phase wise are the exact same volume, it will be super obvious that htey are phasing out.

author: Zack Hames
content: So, while it doesn't affect the phase relationship as far as timing, it does affect the resulting amount of phase cancellation.

author: Zack Hames
content: This is a useful way to check phase too - try to get the two sounds at the same volume, the flip the polarity to see what sounds better. You can also time adjust or slide kick sounds to make them work better together (in milliseconds)

content:
1) Turn off your speakers
2) Download an app with a signal generator that lets you out output a 1kHz sine wave tone
3) Set the app output volume to 0dB (maxed)
4) Set the phone output to max

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: peterlabberton
content: Hadn’t thought of it, but my initial answer is yes with a massive caveat that I believe negates the whole thing. At the studio I was at, I was really 95% of the time tracking, mostly live ensembles, and a good amount of jazz. We had big soffit mounted ATCs. Amazing mics, beautiful room. So I have lots of memories working there tracking beautiful sounding acoustic things that were really wonderful and open. In recent years, I’ve dug much more into aggressively processing sounds/making more creative engineering decisions that often involve mangling shit. So in my current world, I’m interested in higher rates to push off that aliasing issue, but day to day am perfectly happy at 48.

author: peterlabberton
content: So I guess to state more clearly: caveat is in my current world I don’t think it *really* matters, and in that other situation I suppose it was nice but a small small piece of the puzzle.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Shoutout to Alan Moore. My muse. Glad to see him making an appearance here.

The biggest lesson I took away from Alan's work is that there are no rules and that there is room to continually show people things that they didn't even know were possible. Don't be afraid to go off-road and embrace your wilder instincts.

Why go digging in the same creative mine as everyone else? It's all a creative land-grab once you venture off the beaten path away from everyone else and find your own plot to explore undisturbed.

author: cian riordan
content: Select the region you wanna promote to the top and hit control+option+v

author: cian riordan
content: Another useful tip is using shift-S to solo each playlist. I usually move the cursor down on the time line, then shift-s, then play to audition whats on the playlist. If you are hunting for a particular word/phrase, you can highlight the region and use control-p or control-; to move up or down through the playlists, then hit shift-s, then hit play to listen. Then if its the one, promote it to the top playlist with control-option-v. If you get the motions in your brain, you can really fly through takes and get a comp together quickly.

author: ehutton21
content: I can look into this, I’m not sure I’m following everything coherently but it sounds like you’re struggling with linking your FB business side account to your personal FB, and then in turn connecting that to your IG page.

author: ehutton21
content: Your IG page should be an asset/partner under your business FB page

author: ehutton21
content: Go to settings and I believe you should be able to add the personal or IG account by copying the ID number and linking it to your business page.

author: ehutton21
content: Meta is shite and I know people who worked there, customer support got hit with layoffs—if you’re not reaching people now your chances got worse. I might be able to assist with this, this is part of my work

author: ehutton21
content: You’ll want the business account to have admin privileges and you’ll want to make sure your personal FB page and your IG are partners to it. I’ll try and find a video after work.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Did you create two facebook profiles or two facebook pages? I have one facebook account, but multiple pages. In facebook business manager I have individual ad accounts for each facebook business page as well as an ad account associated with my personal profile. I can run ads from any of them.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
In facebook business manager in the top left under the business settings dropdown (where you select the account) do they both show up under 'your account' or does one show up under 'your account' and another under 'business account' or other?

One may be 'your account' and maybe you created a separate 'ad account', but not sure.

You could try creating a 'page' on the profile you want to use to run the ads from. Not sure if there's a distinction between a 'business page' and 'page' now, but then you can connect that page to your ad account in FB business manager and connect your IG to the page. Also I don't think you can create two profiles from the same email address.

When you create your ads you can control the 'placement' and only run ads to your IG and exclude FB so doesn't really matter what the condition of your FB profile is.

author: josephmossbridge
content: How do you produce an instrumental for someone? Not like the actual music part, but the collaborative part. What stages should you be checking in with the artist? Do you produce the song one way initially or try a few ways and let the artist choose? I’m curious what someone’s process is when they are hired just as the producer and not a songwriter

author: josephmossbridge
content: I am meeting with an artist to do this and I realized I just didn’t know the process that I should attempt to follow

author: popaganda.
content: Is there a song already or you’re cooking up from scratch?

author: popaganda.
content: If you’re sending off tracks and not in the same room check in when you feel like the idea you had is coming across clear.

author: popaganda.
content: But don’t be precious about your ideas, no matter how hard you worked on it. Always be prepared to scrap something that isn’t working

author: josephmossbridge
content: There is already a song

author: josephmossbridge
content: Awesome stuff thank u!

author: josephmossbridge
content: That’s super helpful thanks so much!!

author: Deleted User
content: I try not to finish the whole thing before sending, just make two or three sections and let the writing guide the rest of the process. I try to keep it as sparse as I can to have more room in the pocket but still have some sort of emotional context to it

author: Deleted User
content:
Ohh didn’t see this- I usually just finish the whole thing in a day or two. But before I jump in, I’m solidifying the direction with the artist to make sure we’re on the same page. Playlist of things and descriptions on what they like about them help a lot. Cultural context helps too. Then we go off to revision after the first draft.

But I also really like “just do your thing”

author: Deleted User
content: No ideas but just yes or no is my biggest pet peeve. I’ve never had anyone like this write a good song. It is usually a losing battle, and I’m not one to rack up 10+ instrumentals just to show it to someone. I’m usually trying to send those off to sync.

author: Deleted User
content: People who write songs or verses all the time don’t request things this way. They have things in hand and need someone to complete the idea

author: Deleted User
content: So I’ve been encouraging people to use beatstars in those cases (if they require music in order to begin writing)

author: ALXCPH
content: Ill usually have a bunch of productions or beats lying around for people who just want something finished to write on. If i have someone who is more engaged ill cook something up, with them in the studio, and if they dig the general Vibe ill leave it there, a little over simplified to write on, and then once i have a topline, chorus or verse, ill finish the Production around the vocal

author: ALXCPH
content: My biggest tip is to always let the vocal Dictate the production.

author: ALXCPH
content: I’d reccomend taking on the role as Beat stars. If you are working with someone who wants something finished to write on and you don’t have your own stuff, get some beats from other producers(maybe people you know). Being able to pull up a bunch of stuff that will inspire the artist, even if it’s not your own productions is actually worth a lot to make them feel comfortable

author: Deleted User
content: That’s a good idea. Curating the beats so I can get them started then figure it out from there and maybe help some of the homies make connections with rappers.

author: ALXCPH
content:
To give and actual real life example.
I’ve begun working with a lot of artist I personally look up to and usually know what they want when coming into a session(but I use the same method for pretty much anyone). What I usually do before a session is make sure I have a bunch of finished beats(my own and from friend producers) that are in their general vibe. 

Then once they come in, ill ask them if they wanna cook something up together or just listen to some beats and get going. 

I usually have more fun cooking from scratch with them if they are into it,
But both are cool. And what ever gets the job done is the right answer.

author: Deleted User
content: How many do you usually bring?

author: ALXCPH
content: Depending on the artist and genre, anywhere from 2 to 50 😅

author: ALXCPH
content: From experience an artist listening to finished beats will usually pick one of the first 5-10

author: cy (sigh)
content: that is a wild amount 😂 i dont think ive brought that much

author: ALXCPH
content: I’ve never had an artist listen to 50 beats before picking, usually they’ll pick pretty fast, if your done your homework. But I like having a little overhead just to be sure. Sometimes theyll listen to a few and then get inspired to cook something up from scratch. It really varies from artist to artist

author: Deleted User
content: that’s really interesting. they listen to a few and go “let’s make something new”?

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah I started  handing off thinga recently but even then the consensus between artists and thenother producers has been that im the main producer. ita abi5 scary at first i will admit but if you work w folks 6ou trust and that trust you  this can lift your work to much higher levels. 

i do worry about the money aspect cause im often barely cutting it but i know in the long run I'm more  likely to get more work through this

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yeah, some do,
Some don’t.

author: Deleted User
content: that’s cool, I personally love cooking up together. real time feedback can take things to different places

author: ALXCPH
content: If you don’t have a lot of finished beats it can also just be loops, maybe a certain guitar or piano loop will inspire them to rap on, then just have a bunch lying around, once you play one that makes them light up, throw some drums on it and get to writing. You can always finish details later.

author: ALXCPH
content: To me it’s always just about getting the song out of the artist. Production always gets a backseat.

author: ALXCPH
content: You might start on one beat. Get a sick accapella and think the beat is not up to par, then use that vocal to cook something completely new up

author: Deleted User
content: Getting some great ideas from you

author: ALXCPH
content: When u have an artist in the studio priority nr 1 is get the take and performance.

author: ALXCPH
content: I’m not saying my way is the only way, but it’s what has always worked for me, and is what has gotten me to a point where I now can live off this music shit. ☺️

author: Deleted User
content: 100% have everything plugged in ready to go at all times

author: Deleted User
content: Ohh definitely. I was just saying you gave me a lot of ideas and the more angles I have the better!

author: ALXCPH
content: When you have the perfect take, you have the power to send that acapella to other producers that you trust, who might do a better job than you on said artist. But you are still the main producer/curator.

author: ALXCPH
content: Also a great way to open up opportunities for collabs with other producer you might respect

author: ALXCPH
content: Having leverage(the vocal)

author: ALXCPH
content: Always kill your ego, and focus on getting the best song possible. That way, your results will be so much better than a lot of your competition.

author: ALXCPH
content: Look at a guy like DJ khalid. A lot of people like to poke fun at him, but he is working with the biggest artists out there, curating artists and producers. While still being credited as the main guy. The dude is not dumb.

author: ALXCPH
content: “Wild thoughts” wouldn’t exist without him. Sooo, basically he won music.

author: Deleted User
content:
I struggle with this, handing off something I started is a bit difficult for me. Probably an ego thing, but also control freak thing. I’m learning to lean into it. Letting go of attachment is really hard for me

I don’t have enough work out in the world right now although I’ve been making a lot of stuff- this is probably why. 

Although I love doing things from start to finish or bringing things to finish line, I think not being afraid of handing it off to someone who can make it happen or making small contributions but on many songs (drum programming, adding guitar or synths) may be the move to get my hands dirty more often.

author: ALXCPH
content: Look at it this way, you could have 10 songs where you recorded, wrote, produced, played and mixed or you can have 1000 songs where you contributed one or two things to. I make my living doing the latter. ☺️

author: Deleted User
content: That’s a great way to look at it. Glad I got to discuss this with you today! I really appreciate it 🙏

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah i juat started handing off things and the consensus w artists and said producers ia that im still the main. i def worry about Financials cauae sometimes im barely cutting it but i know fora fact ill get more work in the long run. my 2 most recent gigs were through those  connects for example 

abuilding a team over time like this ia very beneficial both for delegating and gaining new clients thru trusted sources

author: ALXCPH
content: I have tons of shit out, that I’m not even credited on, even tho I was in the session and helping out. But those sessions showed the people there what I do and how I do it and got them texting or calling me afterwards where I ended up with credits and good payments.

author: Deleted User
content: I think it’s easy to fall into this when coming up cause of the desperation to be able to make living off of just music. Always the best idea to just do great work with great results and sort things out later if needed be. If things don’t work out in terms of finances or credits, then move on and do more. Money will be spent- but good work is a lasting asset

author: ALXCPH
content:
Music is one of those thing where being entitled doesn’t work out. People will pay you for you if they feel they need you. It’s like saying “I did a painting of a spoon, now pay me” but the reality is; if people want a picture of a spoon, and they think u are the person who makes the kind of spoon they want, they will pay you to get what they want. 
Nobody will pay you because you wanted to make a painting of a spoon.

author: ALXCPH
content: A little cryptic, but I hope it makes sense 😅🫠

author: Deleted User
content: Not cryptic at all. It’s one of those things where it’s needed but not really at the same time. Like you said, people will pay for it if they see the value in it but otherwise it means nothing

author: hendrick
content:
so i’ve been working w this artist producing their songs for a couple years for a steady price per song but now i’m looking to ask for a “raise”, since i feel i have more experience than when we started. how should i approach that conversation??

i tried to really go the extra mile with the latest song (as if i was getting paid more) and they absolutely loved it on the first demo. with this result i kinda want to say something along the lines of “hey you can see our quality can be much higher now can u pls pay more?” 😭 pls help 🙏🏽

author: Zack Hames
content: You just gotta take the risk and ask. It’s shocking how often you can ask for something and actually get it, particularly when you’re not being malicious.

author: Zack Hames
content: If they’re your homie or long term collaborator they’ll support you

author: Zakhiggins
content: To play devil's advocate, in my experience sometimes it's worth keeping your original prices with artists you've been working with a long time, and use the good work you've done with them to get more work at a higher price.. The extra jobs you get from good work is probably worth more than what ever extra money you get from one job

author: Zakhiggins
content: Also, if they find out through you or otherwise that you're charging others more, they might be inclined to pay you more too, not wanting to leave you short.

author: peterlabberton
content: If you can do it and not come off as pushy or weird, I’ve sometimes invoiced a client their old rate, and said something like, “since our last batch of songs, I’ve raised my rates; let’s do this one at the old rate but maybe have a conversation next time about it.” Then it can feel to them like you’re looking out for them and throwing them a bone, but setup a conversation down the road.

author: hendrick
content: yeah my gf suggested this bc i actually have raised my prices for others clients haha but i felt awkward bringing that up with the artist

author: hendrick
content: also it’s complicated for people to find me through this artist bc i’m doing pretty much ghost producer work so i’m not explicitly credited ya feel me

author: hendrick
content: this is a great approach!!

author: peterlabberton
content: All the more reason to get paid more!

author: itaylerner
content: Might be a silly question but... is there any real / sonic benefit to using a one SRC over another? I am ABing two identical files, one converted using RX and one using my daw (logic), and they null completely and I hear no difference. Am I missing something?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This is exactly how I do it. When I have a rate increase they Don’t know that when they come back to work with me, so the first gig after increase is at the old rate

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There very much is a difference between SRC. I’ve never done it in logic so can’t say how it performs. I wouldn’t pay too much attention to the null test but if you can’t tell sonically then you are good

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I know RX to be good so I trust it

author: peterlabberton
content: Why would you not pay attention to a null test? Obviously if they don’t null, you need to decide which is better. But if they DO, null… end of conversation, right? Objectively the same.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Even things that null down to -60 or -80 dBFS can sound and feel very different

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If it’s a 100% -140dB null then that is meaningful, and rare

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So it’s mostly useless for comparing things

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I would say that most of the conclusions I see people reaching based on null tests are flawed

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But to go to @itaylerner ‘s question. SRC is not voodoo, it’s entirely possible that Logic’s SRC is performing really well

author: Rollmottle
content: This site shows you how wildly different SRC's can handle aliasing. https://src.infinitewave.ca/

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s just adding zeros and filtering

author: peterlabberton
content: That all makes sense re: null

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It does, but it doesn’t show you the trade offs of steeper filtering at all. It’s not just “aliasing bad, remove that and you are good”. The filters have an effect on transients

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Which is why someone like Daniel Weiss does less steep filters to find a subjective sweet spot

author: itaylerner
content: Fascinating - just went to check again and they null down to -80,

author: Rollmottle
content: indeed. only to show that there is indeed a difference. but still have to listen and decide. in the grand scheme, it's probably very small potatoes.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ok, that is basically meaningless. Choose by ear, listen to transients on snares, percussive elements

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And listen for digital hash

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: In production it’s barely worth considering unless you are on a Diana Krall record or something

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I bet we couldn’t tell them apart

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Go forth and prosper

content: Thank you, oh wise one 🧎

author: spectrummasters
content: Imo it can help the workflow and being efficient , to mix maybe two/three tracks concurrently , so you can keep your ears a bit fresher and not mix yourself down a rabbit hole  . I don’t do it all the time but sometimes it can really help to clear a few mixes that seem a bit finicky ( if you’re looking to speed up your overall turnover). I’m sure others have said it, but taking an ear break from one mix to prep your next , and maybe work on a specific technical issue in another (clip gaining esses for example ) ...can just help me not get bogged down and always moving through the to do list

author: JakeTB
content:
This question is a bit hard to answer, being that I’m not sure I’m qualified to weigh pros and cons.

I guess for my level of investment, I’m looking for the equivalent of telling an aspiring producer to get some John Hunter gobos and little JBLs.

If I can keep it around $100, that’s great. But without really knowing which features to look for, I’m not opposed to spending slightly more (or significantly less).

author: JakeTB
content: I really appreciate that. Thanks Ruairi.

author: ALXCPH
content: Ideally you want the speaker mounted in the wall.

author: JakeTB
content:
The boundary effect is a welcome help in 2023 musicmaking since it helps with your headroom and low end. 

There are other technical trade offs the smarter people can outline, but the energy coming off the wall is a nice thing with the low end in today’s records.

author: JakeTB
content: And as @ALXCPH said above, soffit mounted is best in the perfect world. But for the rest of us, against the wall seems to get better consistent results

author: AJ
content: What are some of the main factors you look for when deciding between mixing engineers? I'm looking to expand my network for my 2023 projects. One goal is to try and hire those who have worked with bands I'm inspired by/wish to emulate to an extent. But choosing within that paradigm is still a seperate ordeal.

author: cian riordan
content: I have thoughts, but as someone on the other end, I’m going to let folks who hire and choose mixers weigh in first.

author: Eric Martin
content: I’ve hired people based on work they’ve done within the budget that we could afford, haven’t branched out of a smaller budget so it has stayed pretty close to home

author: Fatherbobbytownsend
content: Communication and how smooth they are to deal with is high up on my list. And dependable with deadlines.. usually someone I have a relationship with or the artist /label has a relationship with

author: Fatherbobbytownsend
content: I’ve gone on long tidal dives finding dope mixes and then following the engineers on Instagram tho haha. But haven’t hired anyone through that .. yet

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I love this question. Someone with a personal connection, or with the space to build one, will almost always yield a more satisfying result, if not a necessarily better one.

author: AJ
content: Really glad to hear these answers! What are the types of questions you would ask during the vetting process? The aforementioned factors seem like they are great things to look out for.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I’m not sure I have your answer here; the mixers I work with have all come through personal connection… but as nobody else is jumping on this- I’d start with hiring @cian riordan.

author: cian riordan
content: I would suggest making sure that you like their output. Listen to things they've mixed and make sure they gel with your aesthetic. There's a technical baseline that you want to ensure your mixer can meet -- it's usually pretty obvious when they're hitting below it. Like Noah said, a personal connection is great because it usually makes the communication a little easier. They'll be less precious about reaching out to you for feedback/additional files/etc and you'll be more candid in your feedback. Also, if you haven't worked with that person, very easy to find people who have and shoot them a quick note. "How was your experience? Would you hire them again?" From there you can just go down the list of pricing, availability, etc.

author: David Fuller
content:
As a mixer the things I'd look for beyond the obvious (are their mixes good)...
- are they easy to work with? 
- are they open to revisions?
- if they're local, are they okay with attended mix sessions? (Generally past the first pass, fwiw)
- have they worked on a bunch of different styles and done good mixes in all of them?
- failing that, have they done a lot of records in the genre your record is in and done them all well? (Some genres have very specialized mixers, so this is a worthwhile consideration)

author: AJ
content: Thanks so much for the comprehensive answers! I'll keep all of this in mind when I start looking in a couple of months.

author: ehutton21
content: What’s the use cases for mono reverb vs stereo

author: cian riordan
content: Honestly, mono reverb down the middle leaves lots of rooms on the sides, and mono reverb to one side leaves lots of room in the middle + other side. Stereo reverb leaves no room.

author: Zakhiggins
content: I love a clean mono guitar in the left ear and mono reverb aux in the right

author: ALXCPH
content: i was recently working on some guitar stuff. and it was a 3 guitar parts thing, guitars were panned L-C-R but the L & R reverbs was 25% towards the center in mono, and the main center guitar had a stereo verb. it ended up as a really cool blend. so basically   (Left guitar - 50%panned reverb) - (stereo reverb - Main Guitar - stereo reverb) - (50%panned reverb - Right guitar)

author: Will Melones
content: That sounds really neat. So the guitar in the center got all the width, and the ones on the sides got pulled inward a bit? I can’t wait to try this and hear it!

author: ALXCPH
content: if you want the sounds to blend even more, you can swap the LR reverbs so their are opposite to their source. But i preferred the L and R guitars having their reverb next to them a little closer to the center.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Also, Using Mono reverbs panned opposite of single tracked elements is an useful way to add balance.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Tbh I’ve never loved a mono verb on LV, but someone recently made a case for a longer mono verb in the center and a shorter stereo verb, which apparently gives a real sense of depth to the soundstage. Makes sense to me

author: BatMeckley
content:
There is a caveat here, in that Matt and I actually have an endgame here, which is keep the flow, don’t bog down the artist with nerd shit, and give them the best sounding track to work from. Where I disagree is the work to properly align it when it gets back, I’ve found it’s not too vibe killing to just have them copy paste my square wave down on to the end of their track. It’s one extra key command that most people can handle, and gives me (and the artist) the confidence that I’ve fully respected and captured their unique flow and timing. 

Right before I end up moving every word and syllable and breathe anyway.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Beckley leans a little more pro engineer and I lean a little more art pirate. Sometimes leaning one way makes for challenges on the other side.

It seems we agree that you shouldn't compromise the sound of the track just to get some perfect grid alignment all the way through. But you also have some good technical options to make it easier on your end when you get the vocal back.

Right before you're gonna end up moving every word and syllable and breath anyway.

author: BatMeckley
content: Make sure to cut em up on grid because the ending of the burst can be just as informative as the front end.

author: austenballard
content:
I'd probably just cut off whatever I needed from the beginning and duplicate rather than trimming the whole 10 sec to 1/8th notes so it starts and ends the same place each time.

Now that I think about it 10s might have been overkill lol

author: BatMeckley
content: Oh for sure. The point is the consistent shape of the start. You cut the first 8th and then last that across in quarters. Subdividing a ten second clip almost defeats the purpose entirely.

author: LAPhill
content:
If I can offer one bit of perspective from an outsider - As soon as someone pays you more, that is now your rate from that day forward. Everything else is a discount.

In composer land, I had a client come along and effectively pay me more than double what I was making up to that point. After that, all negotiations were done as that new number being my base rate, and anything less was a discount (I love the idea above of marking that discount on the invoice so your full rate is still shown). I sort of felt guilty for awhile charging that much, thinking I wasn't at that level, but then started to notice most clients instantly started to get pretty close to that number, where before they were half of that. Perception is a VERY powerful thing.

author: Zack Hames

author: LAPhill
content: @Zack Hames I don't think this has been mentioned, but it's worth keeping in mind -- it's much, much easier to up your rate significantly with a new client vs a repeat client. If you've got someone that's used to $200 and suddenly you're charging $750, that's going to be hard for them to understand. A new client will just see this as your rate. Not impossible by any means, but important to tread more carefully with repeat clients.

author: Zack Hames
content: Good thing to remember / mention. I think Rauri or multiple people have mentioned to do the next project of a repeat client at the previous rate and then let them know “hey I’ve upped my rate, but I got you this time”. Which is a good strategy if you want to do that

author: popaganda.
content: why do we perceive higher and lower in frequency as higher and lower in space? Is it just because the tweeter's above to woofer? Is it because of the floor vibrations when the low end hits? Is there some kind of psychosomatic explanation?

author: austenballard
content: One theory I've read is that it relates to what part of your body vibrates when you sing. Low notes resonate more in the chest, higher notes tend to resonate more in the sinuses.

author: austenballard
content: There's also a really interesting aspect which is that not all languages say high/low. Some use size analogy, calling low pitches 'big' and high pitches 'small' which might have to do with big, low sounds associated with natural phenomena and large animals and small, high sounds associated with small animals or slight movements (thunder or a stampede vs rustling leaves or a mouse squeaking)

author: Slow Hand
content: Hmmm. Low frequencies are harder to localize with our ears and end up feeling enveloping and "everywhere". On the other hand, high frequency sounds are much easier to assign to a specific location in space and end up sounding like they're actually emitting from the speaker which is usually at ear level. Perhaps that's part of it.

author: peterlabberton
content: I’ve personally never had that association of frequencies and height—though I’ve heard other people talk about it 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Slow Hand
content: Y'know, I never really felt that way until I got some subs. Now I get it.

author: sukhuno
content: Could be that lower freq are omnidirectional (including the ground) whereas higher are directional and more likely to shoot at your head vs everywhere

author: Will Melones
content:
Are the sides in phase? Two ways I’d consider approaching this.

1. Put a multi-mono Trim plugin on the track. Unlink the channels. Tweak the gain on one channel until they match.

OR

2. Create two mono tracks and ctrl-drag the stereo clip onto them. Clip gain, nudge, nip, and tuck as needed. Then ctrl-drag the two mono clips back onto the stereo track.

author: Will Melones
content: But if you null test the channels and they’re the same content with slightly different level, might as well just split ‘em into mono and lose one half

author: BatMeckley
content:
Orrrr… just split into mono, take one side, and make that your 808. I just did that on a record. Was better than trying to finangle the whole both sides bit. Track was significantly better too just having the one up the middle.

(Edit: just saw will’s answer. This is the way)

author: cian riordan
content: Great answer. My less thoughtful one would be - split to mono, use the louder side. A panned 808 has little to zero value in the stereo field… especially if you’re unsure of what processing is on it.

author: Deleted User
content:
I was asked to produce a band music, but it’s gonna be a remote production… They want me to put some synth-y elements and maybe come up with some bass riffs. how can I go about setting up the process?  

Some songs are written, others aren’t written yet

author: Adam Thein
content:
You'll probably want to decide this with the band depending on what's comfortable for them, but I generally work on this type of project in one of two ways:

1) Realtime over zoom/audiomovers - I'm sharing my screen and audio with the artist/band and coming up with sounds and parts in real time and getting their feedback in real time 

2) snail-mail style where I get some input and references on what they're looking for stylistically and I take a stab at it and send a version, rinse and repeat until everyone is happy

author: Deleted User
content: Thank you for your answer! How do you go about rehearsals? Do you ever do rehearsals together over the screen?

author: Adam Thein
content: Sorry I’m not sure if I totally understand - do you mean helping them rehearse before they start tracking to give notes, etc?  Or more like trying to rehearse for a live performance together remotely?

author: Deleted User

author: cian riordan

author: Adam Thein
content: Have they ever recorded their rehearsals before?  Maybe check with them and the problem might already be solved if they can show you a recording and you can see what quality you are working with

author: mario dones

author: mario dones
content: I’m used to the brutal and hard parts being on the artist side. I got into mixing and production to help artists through this shit. To help usher out more good music. The more I can do that, the better. It’s been coming at me differently than I expected. I’m thankful to be real. I really started the year thinking I’d specialize in mixing, but the goal has been to be as helpful as possible. I’m definitely having to pivot a bit. Rather than getting as many mixing clients as I can, I’m doing reproductions, or learning to tune vocals, hopping in a writing session. I was confident I could learn to mix, I didn’t think I could bring value in those spaces tho. But here I am.

author: BatMeckley
content:
No.
I’ve had multiple 335s direct from Gibson that didn’t sound like good 335’s 😂. 

Having said that, I’ve played $500 epiphones that bury their $5000 Gibson counterparts.

My take is you always want to play the guitar unplugged. See if it resonates, rings, and sustains acoustically. THEN if that’s all good, you can worry about pickups. And you don’t have to a virtuoso to tell. I remember being thirteen and trying every Mexican strat at the Sherman Oaks guitar center and one was just clearly better. I still have it to this day.

author: cian riordan
content: Silly and obvious answer, but it's the only one I think will really get you there: just do the reps. Mix your stuff, mix your friends stuff, mix anything you can get your hands on. Focus on getting a consistent sonic landscape, despite the source material. Figure out what about old or modern records you like; what you don't like. The world already has plenty of vanilla mixers that make things sound like everyone else, find a way to set yourself apart from the rest -- it's become a very crowded space and anything you can do to make your thing special will work in your favor.
