author: Zack Hames
content:
Tape Machine question:

When people run to tape machines now, are they mostly just running through the electronics of the machines or are they really recording it to tape? How much of the sound is the machine vs the tape itself?

author: Eric Martin
content: I think it would be for the sound of the tape and machine itself, live printing off the repro head into tools

author: Eric Martin
content: for others it could be about the limitations also, only 16 or 25 tracks, waiting for rewind to playback all the negative things that drew us all to digital would be the reason to go back to tape to me, the romantic ideal and nostalgia of yesterday knowing it won’t be a “modern” record

author: Adam Thein
content: Got an Otari recently and definitely a slight sound to just the machine but most of the stuff you want happens when running onto tape.  Like @Eric Martin said I’m recording while monitoring repro head and recording back to digital all in one step and then using a square wave I placed at the top to line it back up.

author: Adam Thein
content: The stuff above nyquist?

author: cian riordan
content: Most of the “tape” sound is the actual tape itself. The level hitting it, the bias, and how the eqs are set make huge differences in how it performs and sounds.

author: Adam Thein
content: Yes - set it to record and you’ve got about 25 minutes to just work before you need to rewind.

author: Zack Hames
content: That's awesome! so you're not even actually recording onto the tape, just monitoring the repro head while it runs. It didn't seem like it could be that simple but it clearly is. that's dope!

author: Adam Thein
content: Keep in mind there is a pretty significant delay from monitoring repro head so unless you are mixing the whole track through it whatever you run to it will be out of time with whatever is not running to it unless you set your delay compensation up accordingly

author: Adam Thein
content: It’s recording to the tape, then you are listening to the repro head a few ms down stream off the tape

author: Zack Hames
content: Ah okay, so you just rewind and it records over what was there for the 25 min or so at 15ips.

author: Zack Hames
content: basically every so often you have to rewind and press record+play again

author: Adam Thein
content: If it’s the mk4 you might be able to set up an automatic loop so it’ll rewind for you automatically and restart

author: Adam Thein
content: But my mk3 can only have one memory location and no looping on the transport

Yes. “My kid wants to make music, how do I get them started?” Is a question we all get.

My answer is always- pick an instrument that excites them, and get them into something local with other kids. The community aspect of music can’t be overstated.

author: Rollmottle
content: Channel strips can go anywhere, but more likely to be on individual tracks. If you think of a traditional console, every channel on a console has a channel strip (hence the name). If you're trying to emulate that workflow, you'd put them on every track.

besides the ones you mentioned:

- 0 to deactivate a sample
- cmd L for loop
- cmd R to rename
- cmd E to split tracks
- cmd D duplicate
- cmd G for group
- cmd U for quantize
- (and most underrated imo) play from note in midi with alt + spacebar

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Shift + ?**: Open *Info View*.

This will open a help window in the lower-left corner and reveal descriptions of everything that they move their mouse cursor over. Including any relevant key commands.

I would put that at the top of their list, because it will enable them to educate themselves as they go.

author: bobby k
content:
got a couple noob questions about mixers having label rates, still not sure i totally get it. 

what's the argument for having a label rate vs. an indie rate? are you not doing the same service regardless? is indie rate technically a discount? the one argument that makes total sense is that an indie rate is discounted because you don't have to spend 7+ months chasing down the payment through a label's bureaucracy. but conceptually is there any other reason for it? also, is that always the case or do some labels have more respectable turnarounds on payment. 

i have one rate and that's what I value my service. I don't see why it matters who is footing the bill. makes sense with production and points discrepancies, but mixing? huh?

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: Questionable ethics, maybe, in not valuing my work consistently and not sticking to a "tier," so to speak. That's where this gets sticky for me. Just hard for me to give a hard "no" to people who truly value my work sometimes.

author: bobby k
content: yea totally! i get the discrepancy on flexibility with the rate, that makes total sense. I've also seen some people do a discount for anyone that can pay up front. like 10% or something. no clue if a label has ever worked out for that though, they take so long to fill an invoice it borders on disrespectful

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: Lol yea it's wild! Never done the discount for paying upfront, personally, or ever asked an out-of-pocket client to do so. They just do it of their own accord sometimes!

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: Would love to jam on the ethics here though. I feel sketch sometimes about not being firmer on "my rate"

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I’ll always do the same level of work regardless of rate though

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: That too! Turnaround's always part of the negotiation for me.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
How do they work currently? Entirely in the box / hybrid? What's the thinking behind the Aurora and Grace?

If the goal is solely getting digital to the PMCs, the RME interface + ARC USB controller is a cost effective solution (lots of posts on it here)

author: owengineered
content: He currently works all in the box. The thinking behind the Aurora is to have high level conversion, and  to potentially be able to add a summing mixer into his workflow. The thinking behind the Grace is simply to have a volume knob and be able to switch to a 2nd pair of monitors if needed.

author: Adam Thein
content: +1 to taking a look at RME with their ARC controller.  Just made this move for my 6-2s to have a digital volume control and I’m really pleased.  Depends on what the other I/O needs are and how much they’d want to spend.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Ah gotcha. The extra IO makes sense if the summing mixer is eventually added.

For now though, if he's going to run digital to the PMCs, the monitors themselves will do the DA conversion, so investing in standalone converters for this purpose would be redundant.

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, I'm tracking this album all by myself, and I'm doing everything else, too - playing all the instruments, etc. My question is (relating to drums): If one of my rack toms is a liiiittle of out of tune, is that something I can "scosh" into place in post, or is that something I have to be dead certain about from the get-go??   Things are just getting a little wild at the moment and it's got to the point where I really don't know what I'm hearing anymore. I'm not planning on using any samples.

author: cian riordan
content: You won’t be able to fix it. But also might not matter as much as people think it does.

author: cian riordan
content: Get them sounding like toms… and just make sure the intervals between the drums are in the ballpark of what you’re going for. And in this situation, a deader drum will work in your favor.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Okay, sweet! I understand everything you laid down. Thank you so much. No one has ever noticed anything wrong with my toms, but man - when it's just me going back and forth, and back and forth, and back and forth,  listening and recording. Omg. I've about reached my limit! Lol

author: Maxim
content:
Time + work ethic is the combo you’re looking for. You’re not getting anywhere without those. 

But I understand how that answer isn’t exciting. Maybe asking “what are people at that level doing that I’m not?” might get you more interesting answers. But there aren’t any short cuts.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Edit: (I misread your message and thought you said how do you make a hit WITH them, not like them, but I like what I said anyways so I’m leaving it up) 

Two key skills that are required before people get let into those rooms:

- You must already be so good at making music that you can do something of importance better than they can. That’s why they brought you in. To help them 

- You must be a patient and active listener who can read the norms of the room and act within those norms in a way that puts others before yourself

author: Slow Hand
content:
It all starts with a well-written song. That’s the foundation of a hit record. 

The production and engineering are important and worth doing well, but if the core song isn’t as good as it can be then it’s much less likely to be a hit. It’s worth focusing a lot of your efforts on making the song as compelling as you can.

author: peterlabberton
content: This isn’t exactly answering your question, but I’d try to first get your head around the very basics (signal flow, good start!)—and then as soon as possible after that, try and get in on a late night when the studio is open or book a couple hours and try and get something recorded with some buddies in there with you. I guarantee you’ll have a sense of how to make it happen, and you’ll screw it all up your first time, and you’ll learn a ton from it.

author: cian riordan
content: Hoo boy. Tell you what, here's something I wrote about it 10 years ago... maybe it'll still be useful.

author: cian riordan
content:
1) a strong work ethic: You have to be willing to put in the time and energy into the project. You will always be the first person there and the last to leave. Once you accept this and work it into your life, it just becomes the way it is!

2) a good personality: You need to be good around people. Half of this job is psychological. You have to know when to speak up as well as when to not say anything. Talkback etiquette is crucial. Learn to read people. Never get angry or passive aggressive. You always need to be voice of reason. People have to trust you.

3) a solid skill-set: You have to always know what your doing and be confident in your abilities. Know the technical side of things. You should also be musically inclined. Be curious! Why does a song sound a certain way? How did they do it? If you don't care and don't want to know – you should do something else.

4) actual follow through: You'd be surprised how many flaky people work in this business. If you're a guy that does things when you say you'll do them and answers phonecalls/emails in a timely manner, then you're already leagues above most other people.

5) the ability to network with people and capitalize on your relationships is the only way to move forward in this business. Going to shows, parties, events, etc. You never know where work is going to come from.

Your work gets you work. Make sure everything you do is the best representation of your abilities. Don't choose which projects to care more about. Give it your all on everything... even if its a shitty gig. That word will spread and you'll start getting more work through that.

Hope this helpful. Good luck!

author: NoahNeedleman
content: There was a point few years back where I adopted the motto "be who you needed when you were younger."

author: NoahNeedleman
content: We're lucky enough to have found this place, and now we're all continually pushing it towards that very thing.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: In the spirit of that, I want to share some dumb shit I learned on the last song I was working on, that I probably should've known but never really did.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Had an artist I worked with a few years ago call me last week for a new song. Now when i tell you there were maybe two good tracks on the record we did... I mean even if the songs were good, my work was terrible.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I'm seriously surpised he would even call me to do another song.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: But he did, and I managed to get the basic production in order, (drums from @JustinLeu helped a ton,) and ready for vocals on monday. Finished the production on Tuesday and hit notes this morning early before packing.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: When he sent notes they were right in line with my own thoughts, almost to the note.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: All that backstory is to say the process has been easy, and fun, and is already his fav track we've worked on without even being finished

author: NoahNeedleman
content: But I remember the last record we did together was NOT fun for me.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: So I've been asking myself WHY.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Why is this time so easy?

author: NoahNeedleman
content: And I boiled it down to 3 things:

author: NoahNeedleman
content: 1) both the artist and I are a little older, a little better, and we hold things a littler looser now.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: ( i know that's true because we talked about it before tracking vocals. )

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I used to think i deserved better clients, now I'm just grateful for the work.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: 3) and this is most important part

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I used to think acting important made me important, now I just want to take care of the people I work with.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I used to think music was my purpose, and people were just the vehicle to make that happen

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Now, i know that music is the medium through which I can love people.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: And that's the biggest thing.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Texts got jumbled cause plane wifi is shit, but you get the picture.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
I back this so much, man. 

As a young artist I found myself deep in the UK music industry and had some awesome successes but some crushing lows, too. Meetings with the majors, false promises, yada yada… I was like a sapling in a massive forest, in good company but super overwhelmed and without the tools and advice I needed to make a lot of the right decisions. A lot of my collaborators just wanted to make some good music / earn some money and never really offered any advice or wisdom. And that’s fine, no shade there.

But fast forward to now where I’m at working as a producer with lots of new, young, independent artists, I’m doing my best to not just be a guy for hire, but a friend in the industry. I try to give my advice, share my experiences openly and honestly, and empower them as much as possible to avoid the pitfalls I found myself in like ten years ago as a hungry kid wanting to impress everyone.

All about that concept of being who you needed when you were younger, mate 👌

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Being mentored is a wild process. I’d suggest you keep at it to really understand the “why” of his thought process. 

Learning/using industry standard tools is all part of the process. Figure out how to let go of what you already know in service of all there is to still learn.

author: Charlie Deane "Hypn0.iRL"
content: I can’t even begin to describe how much I have had to unlearn from where I apprenticed. I had a much better starting point from the well of knowledge I encountered along the way, but I also absorbed some misconceptions and bad habits too. It takes time and reps and asking lots of questions in places like these to suss out the difference.

author: NoahNeedleman

author: popthetrunk
content:
It seems like your exfat drive got a ‘dirty’ bit set after an unsafe unmount and MacOS is stopping you from writing to a drive it doesn’t know will retain your work. Windows is being less cautious. It’s likely nothing is wrong with your volume, but without installing some odd tooling on your Mac this is how I would reset with access to both os.

Run a CHKDSK on that drive in windows(this will take some time) and then run first aid in disk utility to see if any file permissions got messed up when unmounting.

author: Deleted User
content:
There is no longevity in trying to make every song to be the perfect song. There will be shitty songs, there will be mediocre ones, and there will be great ones. 

Work until you can’t think of anything immediately actionable to make it better. Anything beyond it is experimentation- which you could do, but try not to spend more than 5 minutes on each “what if”s. 

I found 80% theory helpful. 

Do your 80% not 100%. next year, your 80% is going to be your last years 125% or possibly more

There’s beauty in capturing what it was at the time. That’s why we call records “records”. This beauty can get lost when you’re trying to do more than what it is, what it wants to be. I had to learn this the hard way, and I am still learning. 

Because language affects our thoughts, another thing I found helpful is taking the word “perfect” off the vocabulary list too. I’ve let go of the word perfect and had to put conscious effort into not using the word. 

I highly doubt that the bottleneck to you being able to put out a record is your ability or production technique. It’s the idealism. I speak from my personal experience. 

There is nothing wrong with learning, that is great. But at some point of learning- your ability and output needs to catch up to the knowledge. 

Hiring a good producer could also keep you moving forward.

author: Deleted User
content:
You didn’t ask me and I don’t have experiences with Prophet 5, but Prophet 6’s filters are… just magical. Prophet 6 has two discrete filters for each per voice. When you fatten up unison- you can get that packing bump of resonance with the filter. That’s kind of the sound of Prophet 6 thing

OB6 also sound great, my friend has it- but I don’t really have much experience with them. I like how the unison sounds on it, and OB6 uses SVF (state variable filter) and it’s gives this thin, but thick texture. Both prophet 6 and ob 6 have very distinctive/recognizable sound. 

(funny coming from a guy who has NO hardware synth- but I’ve messed with a few of them! + I was a HUGE synth nerd)

author: Adam Thein
content:
When I was doing my deep dive recently - there's a couple great videos put together by Starsky Carr and J3P0 with comparisons.  I think Prophet 5 wins out on raw tone from the oscillators, but the 6 is 90% of that flavor with a much more modern filter.  They added vintage mode a couple years back which really helped it step even closer to the Prophet 5/10, and the modern features like the Arp, Sequencer, and on board effects as well as that very sick analog distortion circuit make it a lot more versatile for sound design (within the Prophet tonescape obviously).

I'm still in the honeymoon phase with mine but I'm glad I went with a P6 personally.  A lot more viable as a performance instrument and it can also get very very very close to the P5/P10 sounds if you keep it dry and keep the filter closed a bit more.

The only thing the P6 doesn't do that the P5/P10 can that I wish it could is the way it does voice allocation in non-unison modes - I believe it always steps through round-robin with voices, whereas the P5/P10 retriggers the same voice for the same key until you move away from that key.  Not a huge deal since you can use Unison 1 voice for basses if you want to retrigger the same voice each time.

author: Josh
content: Oh also for people who want the prophet sound but don’t have the dough, the Take 5 is actually closer to a prophet 6 than than the Rev2. It uses the same voice chips (idk what they’re called) and the same filter. The filter isn’t setup quite the same but you wouldn’t know the difference unless you go full Q on the resonance

author: Adam Thein
content: Also the P6 is a lot smaller for what that's worth - 49 vs 61 and a much smaller body, only 20lbs vs 31lbs

author: Josh
content: Jorb has a GREAT video explaining it.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
unless I've never worked with the person before , am not familiar w their voice + it's a very dynamic song I'd probably have something on the way in . most of the time baked into my input channel or if I'm unsure just as inserts to dial it in more as we go. 

the few times I still get completely raw vocals I basically treat them as if I were tracking. I'll add processing I think is appropriate for the song, while trying not to overdo it, and then I'll automate the clip gain into that to make things a bit more "ideal" when it makes sense.  

often will do this as part of my editing phase. once that's locked in I shift over to mixing mode. might process more  for might leave things as is just ride the some faders /sends . depends on what the song is asking for tbh.

if I'm producing or tracking I usually try to get as close to "the sound"  as possible during that phase  regardless of the gear I have available. even when I get sent vocals I'll ask for both wet and dry but 95% of the time I'm working from the wet ones.

author: Edward Rivera

author: Edward Rivera
content:
@BoozleBAM by the skin o’ my teeth, I’m very lucky to be where I am at in life. 

I could have ended up in the literal dumps, and a few times I have…but I also could have it so much better. 

What kept me from the latter (and put me in the former) was dishing out responses very similar to yours when very important people were _very_ generous with their time, but gave me hard pills I didn’t want to swallow

Even in cases like the one demonstrated on this server, I felt it more like an attack than an intervention. How I wish I could go back to those moments and do them differently. Those people couldn’t tell you where I am now because they rightfully stopped giving a shit 

I had to learn the hard way that their time was not infinite, nor were they obliged to give it to me, nor I deserving of it 

Finding this place feels like part of a bigger second chance I’ve been given, I try every day to treat it as such, and great things have happened because of it

…and I mean more than a kickass drum sound

author: BatMeckley
content: The bigger point here is that it’s really dangerous to assume that just cause you see a nerd behind the desk, doesn’t mean they don’t love or even performed music. A vast majority of the engineers I know came at it because they were musicians in the first place, usually very good ones. They were in fact so passionate about music that even when the artist thing started to fizzle they found a way to stay involved… that kind of love and dedication to a craft usually leads to a certain level of talent. Cian’s not just a fader jockey, he’s also a great drummer. Matt Rad was in punk bands. Noah has played for 10’s of thousands of people at a time. Ruairi I’m sure rocked a pub at least in Ireland and so on.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@BoozleBAM it's worth adding that it's fun to realize that the drum set is just that: a set of drums. The idea that one person plays all the drums in one coordinated set all at once is a pretty narrow part of the whole of drumming, percussion, rhythm, etc. 

There are SO many cool and interesting ways to make "drums" happens.

I would spend some time with some of these records that people are sharing, and thinking about ALL the rhythmic components, both separately and together. 

Take some time, be patient, and try to expand your brain in how you think about this stuff. Lots of good insight from people here and some amazing trails for you to follow. I'm excited for you!

author: BoozleBAM
content: Obviously, I'm much less experienced than all these guys - But a few years ago I went through a NIGHTMARE situation with a producer who wouldn't give me my tracks (I also co-wrote a bunch of songs for him that I'm sure I should be getting some kickback from and whatever else, but whatever...). Once it got to be too much, I started looking for an entertainment lawyer. Ended up with a guy who used to manage Travis Truit or something and he offered to write my ex-producer a letter for free. Really nice and helpful guy - for the little guys. So, yeah. Thank goodness I'm self-produced now and don't need anything from anybody, but the next time I do get involved with anyone in a production capacity or mixing or whatever and I feel like I'm deserving of a certain something, I intend to call Sam up and get things squared away before I start. Also, I'll add that the toll it took on my health - struggling with that producer basically in isolation, wasting time, feeling powerless, etc. etc. - was not negligible. That situation actually made me physically ill, and none of us artist types deserve that. So - take care of yourself.

author: cian riordan
content: If you suffer from carpal tunnel, best strategy is getting the desk/ chair position dialed in... you want to avoid any unnecessary tension in your wrist. Even though I use one, I find trackballs the worst for aggitating my wrist with micro movements. Realistically, some sort of ergonomic mouse and trying to use macro-movements (broadly moving the mouse with your arm as opposed to twitch movements on the wrist). It won't make you fast, but it'll prevent CTS.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Is the verdict in on monitor controllers? All pretty much the same thing??

author: Josh
content: They all suck in their own way

author: cian riordan
content: Definitely not! The trend seems to be moving towards driving speakers directly from the DAC via AES… but for those of us who like the utility of a dedicated monitor controller, there’s some value in taking the minute, near inaudible hit in fidelity.

author: cian riordan
content: Most monitor controllers have analog circuitry and that will be the sonic bottle neck… some just sound cleaner than others, not to mention stepped attenuators vs potentiometers and how they balance L/R signals and eventually shift over time.

author: cian riordan
content: The I/O can also be quite different between them — some will have more analog inputs vs digital, etc. others will have better features for integrating subs and additional sets of speakers. Mine even had a USB DAC and a phone preamp which makes it a real Swiss Army knife in the studio.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Well I’ll kick things off by saying that two years with an artist is a long time and you’re bound to hit some plateaus & frustration points. These kinda of relationships really grow you over time. I’ve never made a whole record with someone where there wasn’t at least one come to Jesus moment. So you’re not alone there. 

But also- you don’t need to reinvent the wheel every time. If you’ve found something that works, letting that be a starting point shouldn’t feel like a loss, it should feel like a win. Use time served as a leg up.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: No room in this business for fragile egos. I listened to @aemaury’s Master Your Mix interview today and I think it might be a good reality check on a few levels. Mostly just encouragement.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Be curious, tinker, learn, grow. Dont beat yourself up.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If it already sounds good to you as is, perhaps you don’t need to worry about  editing it to “perfection”. Follow your intuition here and do what sounds good. 

One can certainly edit tracks into oblivion with certain techniques and before you know it you’ve got a sterile-sounding feel on your record.

I would start by asking yourself “What am I trying to achieve?” and then if you still feel that it needs some editing go for it, rather than working from a technique that you saw someone do and shoe-horning your music into it.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Always always always edit things before adding new things. @BoozleBAM 

Whether or not to edit super to the grid is 100% a creative choice in feel.

That super gridded feel can feel more polished. 

A more natural performance can be more emotive. 

Both are effective at making amazing songs.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Performance > tone always.
Editing and making everything how it should be is more important than the EQ. If things are fucky time wise in a bad way it’ll never feel good.

content: Just set the crossfades, make sure it’s not affecting your transients, and carry on. Not much else to it

author: Edward Rivera
content: Zoom in to your regions and set those crossfades to happen before the transients. If I make a cut to a drum and move it, I’ll almost always drag the region back out to the left and give myself the slack to make my crossfades

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, just to clarify- You're setting up hotkeys so that you can nudge sections in ms increments, correct? Like, for example, you've got a 2ms hotkey or 6 ms hotkey or a 10 ms hotkey, and you're just nudging things along incrementally like this, correct? 1 ms seems like such an imperceptibly small amount, though...? How often do you go down that low with the nudges?

author: Edward Rivera
content:
I set mine at 10ms, easy to tell if I’ve gone too far with even one nudge. Then I’ll set it to 5ms, and go back

And yes since we are in the millisecond range try not to get too hung up on it. I break out this tool if there’s a late snare hit but I don’t go messing around with an entire groove unless it’s noticeable 

The longer you spend on this the less objective you can be come

author: Will Pragnell
content: I own both Addictive Drums and Superior Drummer 3. They are both fantastic tools and I'd be perfectly happy to use either of them for writing demos. If you like to tweak, though, I do think Superior Drummer has the slight edge when it comes to getting the very best out of the sound, and I think the libraries (especially the more recent ones) are a cut above as well. I generally use AD when I just need to get things moving as fast as possible, and SD when I want to go deeper and am chasing a more specific sound.

author: Edward Rivera
content:
I would say pay less attention. When you’re in “hunting mode” you’re queued in on to everything except the part that matters: the music. 

Listen to the song without asking yourself “what else can I get outta here” I think that sets you up for wrong moves, more delays, etc…if there’s something that needs your attention it should be somewhat obvious and a bit basic, not some tiny clinical move that will suddenly open up the record. 

And yet, in some cases even _that_ is true.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I feel this, Ed. I feel you...

author: Edward Rivera
content: Listen more. Hyper-focusing and listening aren’t the exact same thing

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: also the more and more you do this the less you're gonna find yourself doing narrow cuts

author: BoozleBAM
content: Right - I quoted you wrong. lol. My bad. Fixed it.

author: Edward Rivera
content: And to add…the more and more you do this, the more you’ll reach for the fader first

author: Edward Rivera
content: There’s no Grammy for how _much_ engineering is done to a record

author: Edward Rivera
content: I’ve seen Albini engage maybe 2 eq’s on a whole mix

author: Edward Rivera
content: And he exhausted quite a few things before reaching for it

author: Edward Rivera
content: Also, simplify your objectives. Rather than ask yourself “what frequency do I need to zap” start with things like “could this be brighter ? Could this be darker ? Could this be louder ? Quieter ?” You’d be surprised how effective those simple broad stroke moves are compared to surgical cuts

author: BoozleBAM
content: I'm glad you're bringing these things up because I am currently dealing with them all. Much less experienced than everyone on here, but the one metric I keep coming back to is: Do I respond to it emotionally - The track that is... If the performance is flawless and the mix is hitting all the specs on the nerd meter, but i'm not responding to it emotionally, then, I mean... I dunno. Currently trying to reconcile this emotional response that I consider so paramount with the fact that things aren't quite where I want them to be sonically. Sometimes, I think you just have to find the right plugins that will enable you to move closer to what you want sonically without fucking with the flow. Kind of a catch 22 at times. Regarding the plugin thing being good on the stock setting: I read somewhere a while back that most plugin makers put the stock setting as stock because that's where they thought the plugin sounded best. I sometimes feel like if I use a stock setting that I'm cheating as a mixer, but am I even a mixer?? Lol. I'm just a musician fiddling with knobs.

author: Rollmottle

author: cian riordan

author: cian riordan
content: But if I was a one man shop working on a solo project like yourself, save the headache and do drums first.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I ask simply because some of my tracks are "almost there" with me recording drums last, so I'm kind of wishing I took the pre pro (vocals mainly) a little more seriously, but anyway... whatever. I prefer to lay everything against the drums like you said.

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, if I'm understanding correctly, your approach would be to lay down rough vox, guitars, bass, record drums over that, then come in and lay all that over the drums again, correct?

author: cian riordan
content: Not quite. Drums first, layer up. Build the house from the foundation. Don’t start with the roof.

author: BatMeckley
content: Usually when I’m working alone, I’ll sketch rough midi drums, a couple of loops, etc. then lay down a guitar or two and a rough vocal on top of that, if it takes more than two hours, you’re over cooking it. Then I send that to my drummer, who plays actual drums to that rough. I then build all the keeper takes on top of that real drum track.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Okay, right, right. Yes. Thank you. This has been essentially my approach as well.

author: BoozleBAM
content: But I need the song (guitars, rough vox at least) in order to know what to play on the drums, right? Am I not following?

author: cian riordan
content: Pre-pro out however you need wi the drum loop, midi drums, whatever. But when you start recording for real, start with the rhythm instruments and build up.

author: BoozleBAM

author: Josh
content: Keep in mind that “fancy” often means “complicated” which means it’s totally likely that at some point you’ll be trying to fix a set of guitars and realize an hour later that if you mute the send then it fixes the problem.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Basically, as we learn how to make things sound the way we imagine them in our heads, we’ll pick up techniques along the way. 

Getting fancy isn’t ever the goal, but sometimes you gotta do fancy shit to make things work. That will come when it comes. 

Bussing is a really useful technique for all kinds reasons, the very simplest being gain-staging.

author: Zack Hames
content: If you find yourself needing to crank something with a fader, that’s when you pull everything down. During the mix phase rather than at the end or something. And if a source was recorded very quietly, bring the level up at the clip level or within a plugin so the fader can react in an expected way.

author: PKirk
content:
Working on your own music + mixing it is fraught with tremendous difficulty. Record & FINISH your productions. Prep / clean up your sessions for mix. Then chill on it for at least a week before diving into the actual mixing stage. 

Otherwise, you’re mixing something that is unfinished and you’re more than likely to just burn out on it before it’s done. 

I guess there are some people who are good at producing and mixing in parallel. Not me!

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
ExFAT has given me problems so I avoid it. It seems to work for some other folks but these days my go to is a SSD running APFS. I gravitate towards the Samsung T7, they’ve been super reliable. Avoid SanDisk, but I think there are some other folks using things from other brands like Crucial.

Hard drives are super susceptible to damage and weird mechanical failure when moving them around, and they’re much slower. Do yourself a favor and work from a solid state (and keep everything backed up in multiple places)

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: That unsafe ejecting part can really mess up a hard drive because the final writing of some files (even if it seems like any transfers are finished) can get interrupted, leading to corruption. It may not even be apparent immediately

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: And always operate under the presumption that any drive can fail at any time

author: cian riordan
content: Since you’re layering evething up yourself, there’s value in treating every section differently to give you the most control. If that seems weird as a novice, and you want to play through the song, there’s no harm in doing that either. You can always separate the sections down the road and treat them accordingly.

author: cian riordan
content: TLDR: do what will yield the best performance from you

author: BoozleBAM

author: Edward Rivera
content: Id leave it up to the guitarist. If it’s an instance where they’d prefer to run through the tune front to back, we do some work to make sure that there’s no crazy spikes or dips in level with each pedal and that the dynamics of the performance sound as they should

author: BoozleBAM
content: Right, right. Yeah - I'm the guitarist, so I know my rig and pretty much how things should go - No spikes an' shit.

author: cian riordan
content: Let’s say you want the verse to sound thinner or quieter, and you want the chorus to sound thicker and wider… you can do some of this with the performance and your sweet pedal action… but you’ll be able to take it further by separating the sections of the song (verse guitars in one track, pre chorus in another, etc). This way you can effect and mix them accordingly. Just giving you more control and helps the song have more dynamics since it’s just one guitar take throughout.

author: Rollmottle
content: Nothing particularly relevant for most people’s situation. But I have a number of standard DB25’s feeding an analogue loop and another sending digital signal, all using some gender switching cables or adapters to get them to work where I need them. I wouldn’t let DB25 be the deciding factor of going one way or another, but if you do, plan ahead and get ready to pay.

author: Rollmottle
content: DB25's are an order of magnitude more difficult to DIY than XLR's so in many cases it makes more sense to just buy DB25's and save onseself the time and headache. The same argument can be made for XLR's too but I'd say it's a more worthwhile pursuit for most engineers to know how to wire XLR's up. As always, time is money so one must weigh the trade offs.

author: David Fuller
content: Not a dumb question, but no, that's not the thing that causes tubes to wear out (though it's logical to think that would be the case) - rather, having them on causes the cathode to gradually wear out, and turning them off and on again will cause the heater to eventually fail like an incandescent lightbulb.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Not solely but definitely the bigger factor

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: An easier way to think about it, when either channel needs new tubes you will be replacing both channels anyway

author: centonomic
content: Does anyone have a reccomendation for what kind of digital multimeter I would need to measure output voltages of my interfaces and other audio gear? Or does such an activity require an oscilloscope? No matter how many times I read forum threads or stare at spec sheets and dBu dBV VRms conversion tables I never am able to assemble the information in my mind. I’d like to be able to measure output at various levels of attenuation in the hopes that i’ll finally be able to understand with some hands on experience. not sure where to put this question either, forgive me if this is the wrong section.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Hi there, is this for calibration to some level standards. Or are you just looking to learn?

author: centonomic
content: i have a suspicion being able to take measurements would help me make the (probably very simple) connections betweeen various pieces of info

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ah ok. Learning is good.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The EEVblog multimeters are the best value for money -  https://eevblog.store/collections/test-equipment

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Any of the ones here will do what you need, you should be able to find on Amazon

author: centonomic
content: thank you, i enjoy his channel

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But zooming out, I’ve been engineering for 30 years and have some very expensive multimeters but never use them in the studio

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Most modern gear connects together easily and you won’t damage anything if you clip an input in testing. Just set up a test in your DAW with a signal generator and a decent peak meter

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So if I have a piece of gear that can output +24 dBu (like my Benchmark DAC3) I just turn it down a few dB so it doesn’t clip my AD

author: centonomic
content: all good very good points. thank you.

author: centonomic
content: thanks for the info. the first part of you answer is exactly what i want to do. Various forum threads and info around the net seem to indicate that not all DMMs can read the low voltage ranges produced by audio gear. In your experience even low cost units would work?

author: Isaac Diskin
content: In my experience yeah low cost units are fine for basic measurements and learning, just make sure it’s able to measure at least down to mV, both AC and DC

author: centonomic
content: excellent, thank you

author: centonomic
content: ha ha good to know i’m not alone

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s much easier to verify this stuff yourself!

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Skills you will use over and over again

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Helped a friend through a tech issue today - and it was a long parade of  “and what about this specific combination of things?”. There were two fairly simple principles underlying all of the questions, and if learned once would pre-empt the next 50 questions too

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It occurred to me that specific knowledge like asking a helpline person how to connect A to B is brittle. As soon as you swap B for C you have to go searching again

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If you can go a layer deeper and gain an understanding of an underlying principle then you are much more flexible and resilient

author: spectrummasters
content: Edward De Bonos book "lateral thinking" is brilliant on this. In order that we can deduce helpful / survival info from the sensory deluge of  our external perceptions we look for patterns in everything. This is helpful until new information comes along. The choice then is do you break up the old pattern and reconfigure to accomodate the new information , or do you discount the new information to protect the old pattern .Sort of speaks to everything in life

author: Zack Hames
content: You can Key the kick or snare tracks to a gate on the room mics to get more emphasis on the shells vs the cymbals. Sometimes this can help avoid washy crappy room sound. R88 is one of my favs for rooms tho

author: Zack Hames
content: Also…compromise perfect fidelity for energy/emotion/intensity. I’ve been leaning on that a lot lately with success. Maybe there’s a little too much high mid. But when you remove it, it’s lifeless. Try to find that balance of aggressive and rockin’ but easy to listen to

(i'm always chasing the "golden hour" drums)

author: spectrummasters
content: I like a parallel for all my music elements that goes to a pitch shifted (+12) microshift , little decap and into a verb . I’ll feather that in a breakdown or chorus etc . Lovely for a little unheard icing

author: spectrummasters
content: Vocals and BVs have separate buses and vocal fx and all other FX have a separate bus .

author: spectrummasters
content: Like you I find this gives me so many ways to create the cross talk I want between elements . Eg . I don’t like side chaining a kick to a bass at channel level but I do like my different buses to duck each other a tiny amount (0.5 -1db max ) in pertinent hz ranges pre 2 bus

author: spectrummasters
content: Verbs at the mo , usually three or four  . Liquidsonics bricasti small room a , super plate , capitol chambers , trueverb . And I use a Valhalla hall for bvs .

author: spectrummasters

author: Zack Hames
content:
PMC twotwo8’s were a step in the right direction for me of what was possible. PMC 6-2’s have been “easy mode” compared to any other speaker I’ve ever used. (Typical offerings from Yamaha, Genelec, Dynaudio, JBL and some other brands like Emotiva). 

I’ve never used ATC’s, mums, or Neumann. But at a certain level it’s about what works for you. 

I find the entry level Kali’s to be the best bang for your buck early on. If you’re on Yamaha HS8’s or KRK’s and NOT happy with your results, id consider them. Everyone I’ve suggested them to ( mostly musicians and producers) love them and whenever I hear them I don’t feel like I’m in some weird EQ’d hellscape

author: onanisland
content:
First you have to figure out if its the Speakers or the Room. Most often its the room.

I'll reiterate what @NoahNeedleman & @David Fuller said but with real-world example. 

I've had people come by and ask to check their work in my room (because its a "no-compromise" aka what you hear is what you get) though I told them to get a bunch of their stuff if they want to find out where exactly they're making the same mistakes. We eventually saw the pattern and then they'd either have to compensate for that, or fix their rooms.

author: spectrummasters
content: I’m wondering about general principles of mixing a drum kit , from the perspective of experienced engineers ……when it comes to the particular drums ( kick in and out for example ) which are close mic’d with two different mics, when it comes to the tiny timing differences of when that drum beat arrives at the kick in ….and  the kick out …..are you on principle , leaving that phase relationship captured on the consequent drum multitrack ….or are we on principle aligning those kick in and and out tracks so the transients can align bang on with no (millisecond ) out of phase relationship . My thoughts are I want those kicks hitting spot on together , but then I’m corrupting the phase relationship of the bleed in the kick out to the rest of the kit . So are y’all then chasing this phase shifting around the kit multitracks and trying to build a drum mix that represents the sounds as though they all arrived at the close mics at the same instant …..or are these discrepancies of the sound travelling different distances to the close mics ……to be preserved ? I’ve experimented and will continue to do so , but I wonder if there’s a consensus principle around this time / distance to phase aspect of recording and mixing drums ?

author: spectrummasters
content: I’m thinking about not wanting the speaker to be trying to push and pull at the same time on playback if these time / phase relationships are left “as it happened “ during recording .

author: gatewoodsensei
content: @thegreatcarsoni Whenever a breach happens, by law you have to disclose that information rather quickly. Nord didn’t release anything surrounding it for about a year. And they downplayed it saying basically “well… nothing bad could really happen from this” - actually part of the hack was the attacker grabbed some TLS keys so in theory, the attacker could create a fake website and use it as a watering hole type of attack. TLDR. Proton for the win.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
One thing that’s important when getting acclimated is listening to a LOT of music. If the monitoring is truly good, when you listen to your favorite records you’ll be able to hear things in a fresh way, sometimes details you’ve never noticed will jump out.  

And then when you go back to your record you should be able to hear the distance between the two things fairly quickly. Things like low end, transient response, reverb tails, midrange detail (or lack thereof if you make metal) etc. 

Sometimes just the fact that you can *hear* things makes you feel like it sounds good, but the key is to know what “good” is for each case.

author: cian riordan
content:
Kick EQ:
- Mostly just scooping out the boxy low mids. Adding low end and a hair of high end. That ~800hz move is to pull out the ‘boing’ inherent in the sound.

author: cian riordan
content:
Snare EQ:
- Just taming a bothersome resonance and adding in a little snap.

author: cian riordan
content:
Rooms:
- Just pulling the muck out. There was some cool, usable low end in there once I scooped out the bad stuff.

author: cian riordan
content:
Whole kit
- I found afterwards that I might have gone a little too overzealous in pulling out high mids, so put a little bit back in and notched out the harshest elements. The low end moves were just finessing I felt needed after having everything focus.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Also….
Try tracking one take 
Track your double
Remove the initial track, and THEN double over your second take. I find this gets the rhythm and vibe much tighter when you double over a double

author: Zack Hames
content: Also, let your bass be the thing that lives below 150hz. Not that you need to hi pass at 150hz. But don’t let big huge wallowing low end eat up your mix.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Also with tracking my mindset is

Always a L and R for rthyms or main guitar. And then quads for emphasis and I’ll go insane with different layers with different octaves. On impactful parts that need some lift (natural automation as I jokingly call it) I’ll stack a distorted l/r octave down on some hits with like a pitch pedal or octave fuzz, but it’s never to stand out or be heard it’s just like when I need the rthyms to feel larger than the previous section.


Quads of the same octave help reinforce the tone than trying to be a whole other part sonically

author: hyanrarvey
content: Won’t quad the whole song tho. Choruses, main riffs, breakdowns, big chugga parts, whatever needs it

author: hyanrarvey
content: I am really big on being a crackhead with summing multiple mics on multiple cabs with multiple heads down to one track so I don’t have like 30 guitar tracks in my daw.

author: hyanrarvey
content: But like you can screw that up pretty quick if you can’t understand how to get one massive tone with 1 mic

author: hyanrarvey
content: But if I don’t have a plethora of gear and only have plugins or an amp sim, I am still fine cause I’ll track that way mentioned above

author: hyanrarvey
content: I am also big on the single guitar down the chorus or big parts + the l/r that can always sound dope

author: Zack Hames
content: Think to Cian’s quick drum mix.

author: Zack Hames
content:
The slowest way to learn is to work by yourself, hands down. 

Want to get better at recording and mixing? Work with others material.

Want to finish your own material? Involve trusted people. There is  always a risk. But it’s just music. You can mix it yourself or have someone else do it if it fails. 

Time clearly is not an issue for as long as you’ve been spending on this. Whats the difference between 6 more days or 6 more weeks at this point?

author: Zack Hames
content: I see a lot of my self in your questions, and I know this may seem dramatic, but it all seems rooted in fear.

author: Zack Hames
content: Our favorite artists are fearless. Remember that.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Last tidbit:

you’ll write more songs. If you’re so nervous about these being the be all end all, you’re gonna have a short creative lifespan.

author: Zack Hames
content: Not to be a hardass. This all said with love.

author: Zack Hames

author: BatMeckley
content:
You keep getting the right answer. And you keep swearing it’s the wrong one. 

Release some songs. 

The quote above about hindsight is so spot on. If you have 16 full lengths RELEASE A SONG. You can always redo it with the wisdom you’ve gained in hindsight. But you keep asking for help, because you don’t know the answer, you keep getting the answer, and then you go “no that’s not the answer”. It IS the answer. This is how to get where you want to go. 

I totally get that living in the potential is cozy and safe. But it’s not how you actually progress. You have to face the actual. And if you don’t, you won’t. No amount of discord or Reddit is going to actually get you there. It’s like a guy going on a body building forum for two years asking about weights and reps and form and saying how he’s not gaining any muscle, and then it comes out that you actually haven’t lifted a weight yet. 

It’s always “I JUST need this, and THEN I can…” but, again, (again again) it’s not. You need to actually listen to the advice or what are we doing here?

author: itaylerner
content: How do people set prices on gear?? So bizare to me. I shot out BAE 1073 the other day vs one of th newere 1073SPX and the difference felt so minute. but the BAE is almost three times the price.

author: cian riordan
content: Sometimes the quality of workmanship and materials will not necessarily equate to sounding 3x better. They will likely last longer with better built power supplies, better switches and pots, etc.

author: cian riordan
content: I had a pair of those golden age pres years ago and EV and I would use em alongside his 1064s and 1081s and they would pack a huge punch… but they were built like absolute shit and the switches became unusable  after 6 months of heavy use

author: itaylerner
content: Make sense… so is it like a premium for a higher likely hood of consistency and longevity?

author: itaylerner
content: And with new smaller companies making clones and stuff, you’re not *necessarily* cutting corners in terms of functionality (although you might be), but rather you’re paying less for a higher risk of failure?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
There is no one reason that some gear costs more than others than does the same job

It can be everything from component level differences that are beyond a typical engineers understanding to the level of service to where it's manufactured to outright emperor's new clothes scammy stuff (loooking at you Antelope 10M)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: G-Man and I have had a long running argument about speakers, he believes PMC/ATC costs too much

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I know the inner workings of PMC at a component level, and the business inside out. No one is getting rich at PMC, they cost what they need to cost to make the business viable for a product made in the UK

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But that does *not* mean that you or anyone else finds them to be good value

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Manufacturing audio equipment is an absolute heartbreaker

author: wcalebparker
content:
Not exactly a direct contribution to this discussion, but it feels relevant.

I know a few producer/player types who are massively talented and could get great results with anything. That said, all their gear is either really expensive or rare/unobtanium. It seems like there’s something about having this top notch stuff that really gives them confidence in their creative decisions. It’s inspiring to them and the people they work with.

It’s helpful to know yourself and know your clients! Having some inspiring stuff around can be very helpful. And if an artist is going to get excited about singing into a BAE and not a Golden Age, that’s at least something to consider.

I’m also not saying that gear sounds the same. It doesn’t. It’s just that (like Ruairi and Cian said so well) that sometimes gear makes a different difference than the manufacturers would have you believe.

This is so good. I wish more gear discussions started with “I love using this piece and it’s inspiring/fun to use,” or “this solves a real problem for me,” rather than feeling like we’ve gotta justify a purchase cause it “sounds better” or whatever.  Gear can be inspiring and fun in wildly different ways to different people and I think it’s so sick when we lean into that and call it like it is rather than feel like we’ve gotta justify purchases with objective reasons all the time.

author: bobby k
content: This has been my first experience managing myself as a producer and I feel a little stuck in the whole deals side of things. I have a great lawyer. It’s a major label artist. But…who is actually supposed to have the conversation negotiating fees and points? Lawyer to lawyer? Me to manager? Me directly to label? I kind of feel like an idiot asking this but it’s not written down anywhere. My old manager was so good at this but he is retired and I’m wanting to respect the boundary.

author: chrissorem
content: You could create a fake manager email for the meantime so that you it isn’t “you” negotiating

author: Calvin Lauber
content: In my experience with major label stuff,  it’s always been a conversation had lawyer to lawyer, usually the artist/management proposes a deal conveyed through their lawyer to mine, and then we have a quick chat about things that might be missing or could be better for me, my lawyer conveys that back. I don’t personally communicate with the artist directly in these kinds of deals, it’s great to be able to keep that separate when possible

author: bobby k
content: Yea there are very few cases where I think talking directly to the artist is best and this would not be one of them. Fake manager is not the move in my opinion. Im going to get ahold of lawyer first then connect w the manager who I have a solid relationship with. Thanks guys.

author: cian riordan
content: I am in this situation and if it's major label or major artist, I'm having my attorney work out the deal. They will be in touch with artists management & legal and hash it out. All to the tune of 5% of the total fee.

author: cian riordan
content: If its an indie label or indie artist, I'll give the option to send over a boilerplate mix agreement to see if I can keep my lawyer out of it and save the 5%. About 20-30% of the time, their lawyer gets involved anyways and I end up bringing in my legal to make sure things are taken care of.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Is this a sign that you should consider having a Manager?

author: cian riordan
content: I would say that if taking up managerial tasks on your own (basic communication, scheduling, basic deal negotiating, and invoicing) starts to eat into productive working time (producing, mixing, etc) — then the 20% fee will pay for itself. If you’re not there yet, just get a good lawyer for the bigger deals and save the $ until it really becomes a necessity.

author: cian riordan
content: Managers aren’t agents, they will rarely get you work. They are mostly there to help facilitate and curate the momentum you already have as a producer/mixer/masterer.

author: Nomograph Mastering

I’ve had a number of experiences this year alone with people who were just plain greedy, to other people who shoot themselves in the foot by shrugging “what do you think?” When it comes time to quote or bill for a service

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: BoozleBAM
content: How responsive is it to vibrato?

author: BoozleBAM
content: Man - Are there any alternatives. Can't find one of these ANYWHERE...

author: Slow Hand
content:
Probably not responsive at all, or only noticeable on less extreme settings. 

Granular synthesis is something that tends to obscure what's played into it. It takes a small recording of what you play and then it chops it into little pieces and rearranges them or modulates the playback speed. So the nuances of what you play often get smeared and obscured. Subtlety like vibrato tends to get lost.

author: BoozleBAM

author: earwormfarmer
content: The way I typically use the fabricat is in parallel as it has a wet/dry mix, and also going more on the large side for slices/grains of audio. So for me it kinda is like how you would use delay pedal, but the repeats have a mind of their own. Often I’m going for a balance of responsiveness and surprise! And if I want it to be more on the ambient side I turn more wet and more repeats

author: BoozleBAM
content: Quick question here, gang: Currently deep in the throws of the Iowa Tundra. There is a tornado warning, and literally JUST before i was about to turn off my monitors, computer, etc. we lost power. The generator kicked in pretty quick, but definitely everything just got the plug pulled on it for a minute there. Hard drive was in, speakers - everything. Is there a chance that... anything was damaged? Any potential "file corruption" or anything i could look forward to? Can you tell i have zero knowledge of electronics and how things generally work? Thanks, guys.

author: cian riordan
content: There's always a chance that a surge could kick some of your gear's ass... but short of losing some in progress work you hadn't saved, it'll probably all be fine when you power things back on.

author: cian riordan
content: Older analog equipment tends to be more temperamental in my experience... console power supplies, etc. But most consumer modern stuff is pretty robust and bulletproof. I'd be mostly worried about spikes coming through your speakers (if you've got them). But if you're working at a reasonable level and not cranking them when the surge happened, you're probably fine.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Everybody who got their gear insured - How did you do it? My insurance company and I agreed on a process: I assess the value of the gear and document it. Then, I take that list to Guitar Center and they confirm or deny whether my assessments are accurate and adjust where necessary. The only problem is that guitar center is being assholes and really dragging their feet and whatever I can understand why. Is there some other third party I can go through? Some "phone-in assessor" or something?? All I need is a signature of an official business. My signature doesn't count because I'm not an "official business" - Guitar Centers would count because they essentially act as a pawn shop assessing the value of gear and buying it in etc. etc. Even if there were another insurance company I could go through for just this gear thing I would be open to that.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: You know. Skipping insurance is always positive Expected Value, (so long as you can afford the replacement cost), at the expense of greater variance.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I'm not exactly certain what you mean by this but i kind of think i might know?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I don't want to clog the channel, but very quickly (and this is quite an oversimplification): If you have a 10% chance of incurring a $10,000 loss, then your EV is -$1000 (-$10000 * 0.1). So you'll lose $1k on average, but in actual real life it's a binary outcome: either -$10k or -$0. Insurance mitigates that variance, but not for free. So you don't just pay $1000, it gets marked up, and  you might pay the insurance company $1200 to insure against that $10,000 risk. The numbers are very very simplified to make the point briefly.

author: BatMeckley
content:
More often than not it seems the main songwriter demos the song. Maybe a drum loop, maybe some programmed drums. Plays guitar and/or keys and sings.

Drummer then plays along to the in time demo. This will be the keeper drums. 

Band instruments then re-played, layered on top of the keeper drums. 

Then vocals. 

Then whatever little extra schmutz you want to add. 

Then you clear some space on the wall for the inevitable awards and plaques.

author: Edward Rivera
content:
Mate, we’ve both put our time in back of house so I wanna paint a picture…

You’re an aspiring chef, but you’re washing plates for 8 hours. You tell everyone in the back, the head chef, and even FOH that you make the sickest dishes. You ask the line, the sous, hell even the owner for help on making your sauces just right, or plating tips, or hacks to get the perfect fries. They give you their time and their best advice, because they like you and you’re apart of the team…but weeks and months go by and you keep raving on about your sick dishes, about your raw talent, how you deserve a star…but we haven’t seen you chop an onion let alone tasted a plate. 

So, head chef wants to have a check-in with you. He says all the things Cian has said to you just now

Is this how you respond ?

author: sarawls
content: Not sure if this should be here or in mixing talk, but recently some strangers tracked me down to record with me because they were fans of one of my band's EPs and wanted to record with whoever recorded it, which was me in my basement.  I'm so grateful they thought that much of it, but recording strangers was never something that had entered my mind.  I had to think for a while and discuss with my wife whether I would even record these fellas.  That first time went well, and now more and more strangers are seeking me out.  It's fun and I'm gaining confidence to feel more like "yeah I can help you" instead of "I really hope I don't let them down".

author: sarawls
content: The thing I wanted to ask about is, how do you deal with notes where you feel that it's making their song worse?

author: sarawls
content: I truly only want the song to be how they want.  That's the end goal.  But sometimes I'm like, "eh is that note making the song worse?"  So far I just do whatever they ask but then I wonder if I'm not serving them in the best way.

author: cian riordan
content: If you've made your case for how you envision it, and they still disagree, I will always defer to them.

author: cian riordan
content: It sounds like there will be more opportunities down the road given your lovely, organic success story.

author: sarawls
content: Thank you!  One real and simple example is this band repeatedly requested "guitar up" "vocals down" over and over again and the guy is pretty new to guitar so it was pretty shambolic, which I was trying to hide a little.  The balance was getting ridiculous, to my ears at least, but I just went with it.  "It's their record, not mine!"  But then there's part of me that feels responsible for them like I can't let them shoot themselves in the foot.  I thought maybe they're listening in a car and it sounds weird.  Or a phone speaker.  Just some paranoia.  I think I'm struggling a little like "when do I step in and try to say something and when do I not?"  This was their first EP of their young lives FYI.   I imagine the more pro bands are not asking you to make crazy revisions.    (and to be clear - the revision notes are mostly great and make the song better)

author: sarawls
content: Yes yes yes that Jon Kaplan quote is so good.  I think I was too nervous and erring on just blindly doing whatever they asked during the revision phase.  I know them well enough now to say that to them.   Although... I'm also mixing a band that self-recorded right now and I barely met one of them the other night and they hired me the next day.  I don't even know them.  I'm not sure if I could say that to them?  Ehh... I'll get used to this.

author: sarawls
content: And for any of you lurkers that are trying to get people to pay you to record them, this is obvious, but I can tell you it works SO WELL.  Whatever artist you record, go to their shows.  Be cool, in both the "hip" sense of the word and the "nice and easy person to be around" sense of the word.  Even better, have your band play with them and be good.  People start lining up to have you record them.  It's crazy.

author: sarawls
content: Playing in bands my whole life and paying other people to record my bands, a lot of the studio people I knew were kind of hermits.  Go to as many shows as you can.  With locals playing.

"The further the performer is willing to go to get attention, the more valuable the audience’s attention-giving capability becomes to themselves. (“Sycophantic” chatbots serve this purpose as well.) That feeling replaces conventional “fun” or “interest.”

author: river
content: Any tips for someone looking to mix more experimental ideas into their work

author: river
content: Things that are pushing the boundaries of what we might even call a "good mix" What if I just wanted it to sound unlike much else but Good

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pick a tool and push it really hard. See what happens.
Use a tool somewhere it's not supposed to be used.
Ask where the trend is for an instrument and go in the opposite direction. See where that takes you.
Invert your balances.
Go minimal. Strip it away.
Go maximal. Keep adding.
Play with dramatic perspective.
Do three fast mixes and each time it has to be radically different from the previous mix.

author: Edward Rivera
content: Yeah that’s the routing. He liked the gml since you can really get fancy with it but any digital parametric will do the trick. You have to be careful with the feedback loop because too much signal will start to produce oscillation _fast_. Be delicate with it, but what’s great is that you can also control the length of the kick drum this way

author: Josh Bowman
content: Make it sound and feel as finished as you can. Then let the ME  see if/where they can elevate it further. I think in modern record making, except in really specific relationships where it’s been communicated, the best result comes from everyone at every stage doing their absolute best and then passing it onto the next person.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is why I’m always talking about developing our musical taste. 

Most decent mics CAN get you where you want to go, they just take a little different processing down the line to make it happen. Even though the different mics basically sounded the same at the end, I can almost guarantee there was some different processing going on to get them there.  But if you don’t know what good is, what it’s supposed sound like, no matter how nice the mic is it will be tough to get there.

author: BakerBaker
content: So I’ve got a few pieces of outboard gear and I feel like when I use them my mixes sound much better. I can’t match it when I mix 100% in the box. I’ve heard a lot of pro mixers talk about how they don’t use their outboard stuff as much because they have to jump in and out of projects and it’s not practical to do recalls. My question is .. when  a project comes along that you’re really stoked on do you still stick to keeping things in the box for the convenience or do you break out more analog gear? Just trying to figure out how to get the computer to sound better.

author: cian riordan
content: If I use outboard I just print it early on in the process. Only real way to stay sane imho

author: hyanrarvey
content: Can’t +1 that enough

author: Eric Martin
content: I get asked about analog mix bus by a lot of local peers because I have a Burl and Manley etc, they’re always surprised that I don’t use them that way, it’s purely workflow. If I have an analog mix bus, I can’t open the session anywhere else while having it maintain the same sounds and that’s a problem for me

author: Will Melones
content: Cursing myself from a few years ago for using an analog mix bus or summing or bus stuff on some songs I thought I'd never crack open again. I've lived and learned.

author: Will Melones
content: And mixed from scratch 🥲

author: BakerBaker
content: it's cool to hear the different perspectives.  thanks for the feedback. printing definitely makes sense when you get to the level where you can trust your instincts early enough in the process. i'm starting to get there.  i'm mainly mixing my own music and always in my own studio so i don't have the built in pressure to adjust my workflow but I can see how you'd be forced to find creative ways to  not rely on the outboard stuff in profesh setting

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Recalling anything that’s not stepped is just not viable given the pace of modern work and the potential for lots of tiny revision notes.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Recalling stepped pieces is better, but still not ideal.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Hey, gang. Hey, team. Um... what's everybody doing when they record hardcore guitars? I, um... I recorded guitars for my album, and I did a really good job, but on a few of the songs the intonation might be just the slightest bit off - Off enough for me to curse myself and maybe want to do something different with my monitoring. It just... if anybody wants to hear it, I'll send a link. Really feels like a mistake I shouldn't have made - especially since I'm such an intonation FREAK. Ugh... Thanks.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Do it better on the next record and keep moving. 99% of listeners don’t care about intonation. It is not going to break your record. 

If Lou Reed can sell a million records and get into the Rock n Roll Hall of Fame with that ear for pitch you’ll be just fine.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Honestly, thank you, Sir. Best answer I could've hoped for, actually. Haha.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Honestly, The last time I tracked this album with an engineer by my side and we checked in with that very tuner religiously. Those guitars were TOIGHT.

author: SawyerM
content: Yes, tuning before each take was beaten into me. Makes a crazy difference

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, if you do four takes with the idea of selecting two - one R and one L - are you tuning before each one?

author: SawyerM
content: Yes, the only time I won't tune is if it's punching into short parts... if it's just fixing a couple bad notes I will do multiple takes in between tuning

author: BoozleBAM
content: Understood. Thank you. Yeah, that's what I did - tuned between each take. Some of the songs are SLAMMING in tune - like crazy in tune such that I surprised myself, but some of the others are just... off a little bit - more than a little bit, imo. Surprised me when I sat down to really do the critical listening last night. I must've just... not been as diligent somewhere along the way. Maybe too much caffeine. Ha

author: BoozleBAM
content: I'm gonna try and keep in mind what @Slow Hand  said, though - about it not being a crazy big deal.

author: SawyerM
content: Yeah, while having really good tuning is sick, a really good performance should always be the #1 priority

author: BoozleBAM
content: That's so it. Yup. thank you for re-iterating that.

author: spookydrums
content: I also think that tuning to the actual key you're playing in is really important as guitars will inevitably have certain notes be more in tune than others on the neck. So if you're playing a song in E major, don't tune your open G string to a g, but fret it at the first fret and tune that to a G# instead. That will help a lot as well in my experience.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I've NEVER heard of this. Damn, wish I would've known to try!

author: BoozleBAM
content: @Zack Hames When you're tracking guitar 2, are you having the first guitar (the one you're playing along to) panned up the center or hard panned? - I tried it hard panned and found that confusing/ hard to get the performance. Also, if I had the guitar I was tracking along to too loud up the center, I would end up compensating or adjusting a bit too much with the subsequent take and I would end up with a quieter take on one side. I had to have the take I was tracking along to really quiet (like minus 28db, even -25 was too loud) in order to get a compelling subsequent take. Barely hearing it was helpful, but I also think it accounted for some of my off-ness in intonation in parts.

author: AJ
content:
I had a 3 month trial from switching to an iPhone in October, and the experience was really bad. So much so that I canceled the trial within 24 hours. 


- When playing a song, it would  randomly speed up or slow down for no reason 

- Towards the end of a song, it would merge the end of a song with the beginning of the next song for quite a few seconds, then immediately skip to midway through a song 

Both of these happened over a dozen times within that 24 hour span.

author: AJ
content: This was a helpful comparison! Thanks for the link. I can see it being a good fit for me based on this description.

author: Rollmottle
content: The crossfade thing is a setting you can turn off. Have had a flawless playback experience through many years so not sure what was going on there.

author: Rollmottle
content: I have YT Music too. It's good. It used to be better when it was Google Play, but it's similar to any other service. Ad free YT is definitely a good perk.

author: AJ
content:
Yeah I haven’t heard of many stories like mine, which could mean it was a fluke of an experience. But it’s definitely harder to trust for my use case after that experience. 

Good to know that the crossfade thing was a settings issue though. That makes me feel a bit better

author: cian riordan
content: Baking isn’t necessarily something you can do over and over again… eventually, the oxide will just lift off the tape for good and it’ll be stuck to your heads and tape guides. There’s surely some decent one-pass reels available in LA or Nashville markets, but if I were you, start off in a good foot and just invest in some new reels to get you going. I assume you’re doing layback and not actually tracking/storing on tape? I have t used the new RTM but ATR has been reliable in my experience.

author: cian riordan
content: Easiest way is grab a cable or some string, put it on the center of the snare (or on the right side of the rim, closest to the kick) and measure out each overhead to its capsule. Match that and it’s a great starting place.
