author: cian riordan
content: Way to cover your bases

author: Zack Hames
content:
here's my 2 cents;

I used to feel the same way - i wanted the snare and kick to be very "Centered" in my room mics and overheads. and i'd get these like, super forward, up front snare sounds in those mics. Then I'd pull up my snare mic. and it sounded...the same.  I found that if the snare sounds the same in the OH's and rooms as it does in the close mic, it ends up sounding smaller bc of phase or lack of variety.

if you're using 16 drum channels and 8 of them sound the same, what's the point?

The OH's and rooms for me with that many microphones, i am trying to get width or energy. so the differences between the left and right is what makes it sound big and immersive, and let's the snare mics be their own thing dead center. 

Now, if I am doing a 1-5 mic setup, I will concern myself more with all of that stuff and try to get the snare to sound really great and centered.

author: Zack Hames
content: I like what @cian riordan is saying, about you can have the snare centered and have width if placed correctly. You have an advantage since you're recording yourself in your own space. you're not up against a clock of someone else's studio or someone else's time.

author: Zack Hames
content: a HUGE thing for me has been to not give a flying fuck what it sounds like in solo. It's a hard habit to break. 100% easier said than done.

author: Zack Hames
content: it's like if anything the weird shitty thing I am hearing is gonna rip in the mix. I love "blowing peoples minds" when they are like "that snare is super ringy" when it is soloed, then the whole drum mix comes in and you would never call it ringy.

author: BoozleBAM
content: This is very interesting - Kind of like when double tracking guitars... the variation can make it big.

author: BoozleBAM
content: - He's talking about centering the snare in the overheads here, though, right?

author: BoozleBAM
content: 100 - A "ringy" snare somehow always sits well in the mix for me.

author: Zack Hames
content: ESPECIALLY dense guitar music.

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, basically, we're saying there are times when one might want to center the overheads with the snare (minimal mic setup for example) and times when one might actually NOT want them to be centered, correct (more mics, perhaps)?

author: Zack Hames
content: I am sure there's a perfect world where the snare is centered in the OH's and is "distant" sounding enough that it doesn't negatively affect the close mic, etc.

author: Zack Hames
content: for my usual big mic setup, the cymbalas are so much louder in the OH's than the snare, it couldn't possibly matter.

author: Zack Hames
content: my OH's are 100% to capture the cymbals, unless I am trying to make the OH's a full perfect capture of the drum kit - ala jazz or folk or something more naturalistic

author: BoozleBAM
content: So, I did my best and looked online and watched like 3 videos and read the manual, but I still CANNOT understand why this thing has 3 "off" sections:

author: cian riordan
content: It's replicating the original 1073 preamp gain knob, which had a few off switches for utility purposes. The old 80 series consoles often had a universal phantom power strapped across all the channels – the off position was a quick way to kill phantom if you needed to hot patch a mic. Also just a quick way to kill signal to a channel if there was a feedback spike or something.

author: cian riordan
content: There's zero reason to have it in most contexts, they're just making it 'authentic'.

author: BoozleBAM
content: And it has two "-20" spots...?

author: BoozleBAM
content: I"m studying this now.

author: cian riordan
content: one is for line level signal and the other mic level signal.

author: BoozleBAM

author: cian riordan
content: if you're using it as a mic pre, turning it clockwise turns up the gain.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I am such a jock with this shit. I am embarrasingly stupid sometimes.

author: cian riordan
content: Those numbers are kind of confusing. The number represents the sensitivity of the input, not the amount of gain being applied. So the highest number means you have a sensitive input source = less gain applied.

author: cian riordan
content: The lower number means a less sensitive input = more gain applied.

content:
Wanted to get some thoughts on if I should explore 500 series or mixing console for my needs. I'm primarily tracking drums and I'm about to purchase an x8p studio, but was interested in working outside of the box more. I mainly do mid/lo-fi type recordings. Could spend up to $7,500

**For 500 series** 
I was thinking starting with:
API 8 slot lunchbox
AML ez1073 
API 560
API 550a
API 512c
RND 535 

and build from there.

**For console ** 
PM700
Tascam M216/M208
Soundcraft GB2R

Or should I just start slowly building a rack unit? Indecisiveness kicking my ass rn haha

author: cian riordan
content: Would try and push for a PM1000 if you're gonna go that route. But these are two wildly different trajectories, both with massive pros/cons.

author: cian riordan
content: Nothing beats the ease and flexibility of recording drums or a band through a console. It speeds up and simplifies the process so much... I absolutely hate recording without one. But will it wound better or worse than a stacked 500 series rack with decent pres and EQs? Probably not... will just sound different.

author: M J
content: forsure and if I stick to the PM1000, i'm committing to a thing where as i would have more flexibility with the 500s

author: M J
content: no wrong choice, just different

author: M J
content: I think ultimately i'll have a great time learning and using either route. I think i was stuck on thinking there was a "best" option

author: cian riordan
content: The advantages of the console are much more work flow and less sonics.

author: cian riordan
content: Things start to sound instantly closer to being finished.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I think a good exercise here is to think about how your particular brain works. Does it thrive in the nuance and detail of engineering? Or is the engineering just a vehicle to be able to PLAY… do you excel in limitation or do you prefer a playground without fences?

author: NoahNeedleman
content: You’ll have limitations regardless, but it’s a good way to decide which road you want to start walking down.

author: M J

author: M J

author: Zeuswayn3

author: Eric Martin
content:
I went through an iteration of using an Allen & Heath MixWiz and it was good until the preamp card fried, got a RAMSA console in as a stopgap and decided that I needed to go the pre route.

Now I have 2 Neve OPX’s, 2 Neve DPX’s and 4 Phoenix Audio DRS’s, and 4 Great Rivers, it’s not exactly a console but functions like it for me and everything is essentially under warranty (for now)

Most tracking dates are done with the DPX’s and some outboard comps, drums are normalled to the Phoenix Audio’s

basically all my “profit” for two years dedicated to preamps.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
also a clipper isn't just an envelope shaper, it's essentially a form of distortion
so if you replace "clipper" with "saturation" in your question, the transient designer doesn't sound all that out of place because as kidcutler pointed out it's doing more than just doing -1 and then +1

author: TroelsHolm
content: Hi! New here, thanks a lot for all the really great advice! I have a question. I seem to never be able to take breaks when I mix. I think it is because I mix from anxiety or something like that. It often times ends with me not making great decisions level-wise because I get fatigued. Any pointers? What works for you work-flow wise for mixing a track?

author: David Fuller
content: force yourself to get up and walk away

author: David Fuller
content: do something else - make a coffee, eat something, go on a short walk, whatever

author: David Fuller
content: anything to take your mind off what you're working on and give your ears a break

author: David Fuller
content: ear fatigue is as much psychological as it is physical

author: Rollmottle
content: Use an app to set a disruptive reminder or to start the screensaver on your computer automatically. Something that will hold you accountable without you having to think about.

author: TroelsHolm
content: Thanks for the replies! How long do mix for before you break?

author: Zack Hames
content:
If you can go outside and take a walk, do it. 

Blood flow increases brain activity. Thus increasing creativity and problem solving.

author: Zack Hames
content:
If you follow the typical computer break adage, it’s like 45 minutes in front of computer, then a 15 minute break.

Might be more like 50 min/10 min actually.*

author: Zack Hames
content: But I usually go until I reach a logical stopping point or if I’m really making bad decisions, bail.

author: Zack Hames
content: Ironically, taking more breaks makes you more productive.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Just turn down the level you listen at

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I work 12 hour + days every day, i never have ear fatigue
